PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos.

This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence.
The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experimentation on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Black (from 342 citizens), Chaney (from 187 citizens) and Reynolds (from 204 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service;
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Beahan (from 10 citizens), Jones (from 253 citizens), McKiernan (from 244 citizens), Vallentine (from 75 citizens) and Watson (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Referendum: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a Referendum to amend the Constitution so that the Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and to care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including to prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office: St Morris, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
The number of people protesting against the proposed closure of the post office located at 403 Magill Road, St Morris.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request that the post office at 403 Magill Road, St Morris remain open.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned respectfully sheweth that you support the National Health and Medical Research Council in their quest for medical research funds for 1989. Medical research covers the whole breadth of medicine. The funds provided by your Government through the NH & MRC support your scientists and technicians whose work promotes the development and evaluation of new techniques and therapies and is essential for long term improvement in the health of the nation.
Under your Government medical research funding has been increased but it still lags behind the major developed nations in terms of the amount expended per capita.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should in future provide funds to allow all projects recommended by the NH & MRC to be supported. Without a significant increase in medical research funds for 1988-89 these activities will be severely curtailed to the detriment of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Tate is absent from the chamber for Question Time today as he is attending the funeral of Sir Guilford Young, the Archbishop of Hobart. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of today's call from the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Gary Weaven, for an easing of wage restraint, I ask the Minister whether he agrees with Senator Ray who said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: The alternative to our current economic policies, if we were ever to give any thought of abandoning them, would bring absolutely dire economic consequences on this country. It can't be contemplated. We cannot change the basic thrust of our economic policies just to win the next election. That would be betraying the country.
If the Minister does agree with Senator Ray, what are the implications for wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Ray. What Senator Ray said has been said by other Ministers and indeed by me in a number of forums and in public. I assume that Senator Ray was making the statement which he made in the context of a general recognition that we did not have a great day on Saturday. I did not hear Senator Ray say that, but I assume that was the context in which his statement was made. In so far as the question of wages policy is concerned, I have been asked by Opposition spokesmen on numerous occasions-and I am not condemning that fact-over the five-year period in which we have been in government what the Government is going to do, for example, about wages policy in the next quarter, in the next national wage case and so on. I have never been able to answer those questions, largely because it is not always appropriate to make announcements about these matters in the Parliament but also because frequently the Government is preparing a position in relation to wages policy or there is some review of wages policy taking place in respect of which one would not want to foreshadow the Government's position.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter at present is that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will be reviewing the wages system in May. The Government will be making a submission to that review. However, the review is still some time away and I think it is fair to say, as I virtually said a minute ago, that the Government is still developing its thinking in relation to the context of that submission to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Of course, in the context of developing that position, the Government will look at the proposals from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the views of various employer groups. I think that Senator Chaney will recall-I do not recall the exact circumstances-Mr Willis in general terms making a favourable response to the approach adopted by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) in a public statement of perhaps three weeks ago. Those views will be looked at in the course of preparing the Government's position for that review. I conclude by saying-and I think it is consistent with what Senator Ray said and the passage quoted by Senator Chaney-that, whatever the system that is arrived at, it must be capable of delivering an appropriate degree of wage restraint and encouraging productivity improvements as part of any wage settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Leader of the Government for that answer-not least for the last sentence of his answer, which I think would command broad agreement. I ask: In light of the fact that the CAI, which apparently has some approval for its comments, has publicly come out and said that it thinks something in the order of 3 per cent might be appropriate for consideration as against the already published views of the ACTU, which refer to wage movements in line with prospective inflation to protect the standard of living--
—Plus.

—`Plus', I am reminded by Senator Stone. I ask: Can we take his answer to indicate that, therefore, at this stage the Government sees that more restrained approach of the CAI as being closer to reality?

—I am not here to endorse the CAI approach. Frankly, I do not know enough about it, apart from anything else. All I was saying in the earlier part of my answer was that Mr Willis welcomed what he regarded as a positive sort of approach from the CAI to the issues which had to be addressed in future wage settlements. I am aware of the ACTU position in so far as Senator Chaney described it. I was not sure that the `plus' part that Senator Stone contributed by way of interjection was necessarily correct. I am just saying that I am not sure about that. Let me say that both those views have to be taken into account by the Government. As I said in the last part of my original answer to Senator Chaney's question, two issues are very important: an appropriate degree of wage restraint and the issue of productivity being addressed in the context of wage restraint. Where the Government comes down in respect of those two issues, of course, it is too early for me to say.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, refers to recent Press coverage of the substantial commitments to export from Australia made by the major multinational companies in the information industries. Most recently, Wang Laboratories Inc. has announced an undertaking to export $300m-worth of its products from Australia in the next seven years. Can the Minister report on developments in these industries and indicate the prospects for future growth in manufacture and export from Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is important when one contemplates the current account difficulties with which Australia is faced. There is often great discussion about the contribution of coal and iron ore, for example, to the balance of payments. I do not think it should be overlooked that the computer and associated industries are currently enormous contributors to the balance of payments deficit which we have. For example, as at 1986 computer imports were roughly at a level of something of the order of $8 billion a year. The figure for exports for computers and associated equipment was in the order of something less than $200m a year.

ANSWER.PARA: It is in that context that arrangements were reached with various companies as a replacement in time for the civil offsets program. Essentially, under that arrangement, transnational corporations that commit themselves to a degree of competitive work in Australia will be relieved of offset obligations in return for meeting agreed export and research and development targets. The Government has moved under that arrangement to initiate development arrangements in view of Australia's trade deficit, to which I referred. Agreements have been reached with companies such as Honeywell Bull Australia Pty Ltd, Apollo Domain, Hewlett Packard Australia Ltd and Wang Australia Ltd and negotiations are being concluded with a number of other major computer companies and several further announcements are imminent.

Transnational corporations that enter into these agreements undertake to reach an annual expenditure on research and development in Australia equal to 5 per cent of their annual turnover by 1994 and, within the same period, reach a level of Australian value added exports equal to 50 per cent of their imports. To date, commitments have reached totals in excess of $800m per annum in exports and $170m per annum in research and development by the end of the year 1994. As I said, negotiations are continuing with a number of other major software and hardware companies. Indigenous organisations in Australia are benefiting from the agreements by the export of Australian-made products. Those that have already benefited include LSE Manufacturing Pty Ltd, IO Design, Clean Line Systems Pty Ltd, Computer Switching Systems and Cables Pty Ltd, PI Systems, Expert Systems Pty Ltd and ISR Pty Ltd. Essentially, those companies are gaining export markets by using the international marketing strength of major transnational companies to support them in markets such as the United States of America and Europe.

Research and development in areas of artificial intelligence, image processing, electronic funds transfers and land information will also be performed by Expert Systems Pty Ltd, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the University of Queensland and other companies in carrying out the agreements to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the Australian manufacturers. How do they view it?
—Very well, Senator Lewis.
—Oh!

—I do not want to mention something so vulgar in the Senate, but let me tell Senator Lewis this: if he looks at the last edition of Computer World-it is very vulgar personally that I should say this--
—It didn't have a photograph of you in it, did it?

—Not only did it have a photograph of me in it, but also some gentleman, whose name I have temporarily forgotten, said that he felt that the program was so successful that I should be given a knighthood.
—We think so.
—Thank you, Senator Stone. It has not been offered to me yet.
—Especially on your retirement.

—Senator Chaney says, `Especially on my retirement'. I have views about that topic. If the program to which the gentleman referred has made a contribution to Australian industry development and to the development of exports and research and development in this country, I welcome it. Perhaps Senator Puplick, who is a younger man, could say something about it in his condolence speech when I finally put the cue in the rack. Senator Lewis's interjection is very important. We had every hope of developing a cottage industry in Australia in computer peripherals and software. The opportunities which are given by the partnership--
—When did the opportunities slip by?

—The honourable senator should not invite me to tell him when they slipped by. Let me just make this point: the opportunities which have now been made available to Australian companies for international marketing are just enormous. I say to those who subscribe to the cottage industry view of the pure Australian software industry with no business arrangements with foreign companies or anything of that kind that we would have had a similar industry here in 10 years time. An industry such as this cannot get off the ground without international marketing presence and muscle. That is what it is all about. So I do not think the honourable senator should go about picking up the disenfranchised who have not yet taken opportunities to avail themselves of the enormous prospects that are available to them.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is about the loans made by the Australian Trade Commission, or Austrade, to Cuba and Nicaragua to support the sale of sugarcane harvesting equipment and spare parts. The Minister may be aware that those countries are in default on the loans and that the loss to Australian taxpayers may exceed $17m. Did the Minister direct that the original loans be made under the national interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act? What aspect of the national interest was advanced by loans to Cuba and Nicaragua? Does the Minister endorse the comments of his Press Secretary today that the outstanding amount was only a relatively small amount? Finally, what would be approximately the total amount currently in default on Austrade loans around the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer the last part of the question in terms of the total amount of Austrade loans in default. I will certainly get the honourable senator an answer in that respect. I do not carry that information in my head. I certainly did not direct that the national interest provisions be used in respect of these loans. I was not the Minister at the time. I am not in any sense seeking to evade the issue by saying that, but Senator Lewis asked me whether I so directed and the answer is no. I am quite unaware of what my Press Secretary said today, but let me say that, whatever he said, I have a high degree of respect for him and I am sure--
—He said that $17m was a relatively small amount.

—I do not know what he was asked; that is the important question. In so far as the details of the Cuban and Nicaraguan loans are concerned, together with loans to other Central and South American countries, I gave an answer to a question on notice about that matter which appears in the Hansard of 22 February 1988. The loans to Cuba and Nicaragua total $17.3m and repayments amounting to $9.1m of the total are currently overdue. Recovery action is being taken and it is expected that full recovery will be made. I should draw the attention of Senator Lewis and other honourable senators to the fact that all loans were provided by Austrade on terms which were in accord with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development arrangements on officially supported export credits and did not include Australian aid funds.

ANSWER.PARA: In extending these loans to support the export of cane harvesters by Austoft Industries Pty Ltd, formerly known as Versatile Toft, the Government was mindful of the high risks involved at the time. Austoft Industries is, I think, one of two sugarcane harvester manufacturers surviving in the world. As I understand it, there is one German firm and Austoft. At that time the Australian sugar industry was in great decline and support for Austoft was considered appropriate in order to maintain Australia's position as the world leader in sugarcane harvest technology-and, of course, in view of the significant employment benefits for the Bundaberg region at a time of depressed domestic demand. I also understand that a detailed explanation relating to the Cuban loans was provided by the former Department of Trade to a Senate Estimates committee and I refer honourable senators to the Hansard of 3 April 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to Press reports that Telecom Australia is considering charging at least $350 a year for home telephone rentals and 50 per cent more for local calls. Can the Minister advise me whether there is any truth in these suggestions, which have apparently been made by the Australian Consumers Association?

—I am happy to clarify the issue, which has been the subject of some fairly spectacular misrepresentation in the media today. I can say quite firmly and unequivocally the following: suggestions by the Australian Consumers Association that Telecom or the Government is considering raising home telephone rentals to around $350 a year and local call charges by 50 per cent are complete and utter nonsense. There is no such proposal before the Government either from the task force reviewing telecommunications policy or from anywhere else. Telecom, for its part, has already stated publicly that, in the current climate, it does not envisage any increase in charges during this financial year or, for that matter, in 1988-89. I hope that that puts to rest what I suspect has been a rather mischievously encouraged rumour which has no foundation whatsoever.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that letters are sent from Department of Social Security offices which demand action of social security benefit recipients and that these letters do not carry a personal signature but only a typed signature? Is it the case that such letters derive their legal authority from the letterhead rather than from the personal signature? In view of the widespread use of automated correspondence, is it to become increasingly the practice throughout government departments that unsigned letters are to be used to direct members of the public? Does the Minister acknowledge that, if this is to be the case, there is grave potential for havoc, given widespread and ready access to departmental and other letterheads? If so, what action does the Government intend to take?

—I thank the honourable senator for raising this question. I have looked through the brief that has been made available to me and, even though a number of questions were anticipated today, one like this was not. I would like to take the question on notice, get more information from the Attorney-General and come back to the honourable senator.

—Does the Minister for Local Government agree that migrants in country areas do not have access to the range of special services available in the capital cities? Can the Minister tell me what is being done to assist them?

—The Government is actively extending migrant services in non- metropolitan areas. Under the grant-in-aid scheme, 11 per cent of the grants made for ethnic welfare services go to communities in non-metropolitan areas. Similarly, nine of the 32 migrant resource centres and subcentres are located outside capital city areas. Within the adult migrant education program, which is administered nationally by Mr Holding's Department under arrangements with the States and the Northern Territory, courses are provided in a significant number of provincial centres. The home tutor scheme reaches people who do not live near centres where courses are provided or who, for other reasons, are unable to go to formal classes. Correspondence courses have been enhanced with the introduction of a new course, `It's over to you', which was launched nationally at the end of 1987. The telephone interpreter service is another unique facility which, in the next few months, will switch over to a 008 number so that all callers outside the metropolitan area can use the service at the cost of a local call. The 008 system will replace the current system of provincial telephone hook-up equipment which serves many, but not all, of our non-metropolitan areas.

—Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce believe that the current level of the Australian dollar at close to US74c is appropriate? I remind the Minister of the fact that he has previously expressed views on the level of the dollar. For example, he said in September 1986 that he thought the level would remain at just above US60c and in October last year, when the dollar stood at about US70c, he said he would prefer a level of US65c to US68c. Given the significance of the level of the Australian dollar to manufacturing industry, for which the Minister is directly responsible, will he now comment on the US74c level?

—The level of the dollar is determined by the market. That will remain so. Concerning the comment I made last year, let me remind Senator Sheil that I said that a number of exporters had expressed the view that they would prefer the dollar at a particular level. I am sure that that is a view that some of them would hold now. It is a matter for the market to determine and my preferences are not relevant.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister will be aware that on 2 March 1988 the first ever draft national policy on women's health was released in Adelaide. Can the Minister elaborate on the main points in the draft policy and how they fit with other initiatives by this Government in women's health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government has a strong focus on the status of women's issues. That is due in part to the direct interest the Prime Minister has in the subject, by his keeping the Office of the Status of Women under his own portfolio, and to the work done by my predecessor as a Minister in this chamber, Susan Ryan, and now by Senator Reynolds. Our concern about status of women's issues is a core of our Government's position. We have focused on that area with a variety of policies and programs and we have elevated women's health matters to a proper recognition, a recognition that is shared by women in Australia. That point was illustrated after we conducted the most extensive consultation ever with Australian women, beginning in 1986. That consultation, which is now being brought forward in the form of a national agenda for the status of women, identified health as being the major priority of Australian women.

ANSWER.PARA: It should also be said that the States of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia have recognised that priority, and the demand that women have for proper attention to health needs, by developing an extensive women's health program and by funding community-based women's health services. It has not been true of Queensland and Tasmania. In view of the election result in New South Wales on the weekend, I trust that the New South Wales Government, notwithstanding the record of the Tasmanian and Queensland governments, continues with the program that the Wran and Unsworth governments established in this field. At a Federal level, Dr Blewett has recognised the major priority in the health portfolio this year and has sought to improve the health system to reduce inequities and meet the health needs of women. It is a major priority.

In 1986, the Prime Minister announced that the national policy on women's health would be developed as part of the national agenda. It would establish national objectives, priorities and strategies for improving women's health and health services in cooperation with State and Territory governments. The development of the women's health policy was initiated in 1987 and a final report is expected later this year. In 1987 the Minister for Community Services and Health appointed the first ever national adviser on women's health, Ms Liza Newby, to coordinate development of the national policy. On 2 March the Minister released the draft national policy on women's health as a discussion paper to give the community opportunity to comment on and contribute to the policies. The deadline for comment is the end of May. Such comments should be made to Ms Newby at the Department of Community Services and Health.

At the 1988 Australian Health Ministers Conference all health Ministers endorsed the need for a national policy on women's health and agreed to participate. Major health areas of concern to women identified by the national policy include: improving the quality of health services to women; improving health education and information to women to enable them to participate more effectively in decisions about health at all levels; and giving greater priority to women's health problems in areas such as mental health, reproductive health, preventable diseases and nutrition.

Within the framework of the national policy, the Commonwealth Government has undertaken a program of specific health initiatives aimed at benefiting women, including: a commitment of $5.1m over three years to evaluate the feasibility of a national screening program, in cooperation with States and Territories for breast and cervical cancer; grants under national health promotion programs to community-based women's groups to develop models for women's health promotion; increased funding to family planning programs; sponsorship of State-wide women's health forums in Queensland, Tasmania, and the Northern Territory; the establishment of a national subcommittee of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council to advise health Ministers on women's health with representation from Commonwealth, States and Territories and non-government organisations; and, finally, a focus on drug abuse by women, particularly of prescribed drugs and alcohol, by the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse as a major target for 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories whether he endorses or rejects the comments of his colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: The fact that the organised conservation movement did not support Labor-despite its record-may see the end of the theory that conservation issues can be dealt with on the basis of deals for delivery of votes.

Does the born-again Minister agree that Labor's unbalanced environmental policies and his own relentless and, in New South Wales, spectacularly unsuccessful pursuit of the environment vote have distanced the Government from those whom he so demeaningly referred to yesterday as `the common people'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no prouder badge to wear than to be part of the common people or the working class. Therefore, neither I nor anyone on this side would regard it as demeaning. To answer the rest of Senator Puplick's question: I was asked whether I endorse or reject the comments of my colleague Mr Kerin. I endorse them because I was never aware that anyone in our Party was proceeding on the basis of deals for conservation votes. I certainly was not, so I have nothing on which to disagree with him. Secondly, as far as his call for a further inquiry into land use management in Australia is concerned, that is long overdue and I have supported it for a long time. Thirdly, in respect of what I think of the environment vote on Saturday, the reality is that the environment movement targeted only a few seats. In all of those seats, the swing against the Australian Labor Party was far less than it was in the rest of the State. My view that conservationists remain an important voting lobby has not changed. It should also be noted, however, that when examining these questions one should always consider the phrase `all things being equal'. I think there were a few other factors, beyond the environment, at work on Saturday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased that the Minister endorses Mr Kerin's comments, particularly:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the organised conservation movement did not support Labor.
Since he endorses that assessment by Mr Kerin, does he not believe that this simply shows a great deal of perception on behalf of the organised conservation movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The organised conservation movement had a number of candidates running for the Legislative Council, as is its right in a democracy. Those candidates did very poorly. However, I can only repeat what I said earlier: in those seats where the environment movement chose to alert voters to the save the forests campaign, the swings against the Australian Labor Party were far less than in any others.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of recent newspaper reports of scientific evidence showing further depletion of the ozone layer, not only in the Antarctic but in other regions? What action is the Government taking to protect the ozone layer? Are the Minister and the Government prepared to go beyond the implementation of the provisions of the Montreal Protocol in taking all possible steps to reduce emissions of ozone depleting chemicals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports. Australia is a party to the Vienna Convention and will be a signatory to the Montreal Protocol to that convention very shortly. As honourable senators will be aware, that calls for a freeze on the level of production of chlorofluorocarbons at 1986 levels and for the progressive reduction over a period of eight or 10 years to 50 per cent of those levels. I have said before that Australia ought to be prepared to go further than that protocol if we deem it necessary. I am not certain I can yet endorse the comments of Minister Peter Hodgman in Tasmania who called for a 100 per cent reduction. If one looks at the refrigeration industry and a few other places that might be a bit difficult at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the report was from the United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration. That report produced some evidence that the hole in the ozone layer over the Antarctic had become worse and what is more that ozone levels have been depleted in a number of other regions. That is disturbing news for us all. All I can say is that I have asked some Australian scientists in the field to evaluate that latest report. If, on the basis of that evaluation, we think more drastic or urgent action is required, I will take it immediately. In any event, I had intended to have the matter reviewed in 1990 and progressively, through the implementation of the protocol, to make sure that if at any time we considered we needed to do more we would be in a position to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. Taking into consideration the various interferences by State governments in the affairs of local government-namely, New South Wales with the questionable sackings of councils and Western Australia interfering in building application approvals and/or refusals-I ask the Minister: What is the Government doing towards constitutional recognition of local government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for his question because the Government is committed to constitutional recognition of local government. The Office of Local Government has prepared two submissions to the Constitutional Commission. Of course, the question of constitutional recognition of local government now rests very much with the Constitutional Commission. We have had two reports from advisory committees-one from the Economic and Trade Advisory Committee which was supportive of constitutional recognition of local government and one from the Distribution of Powers Advisory Committee which was less supportive and obviously did not see how the necessary recognition could be applied.

ANSWER.PARA: I am certainly very optimistic that the Constitutional Commission will take into account the importance of local government. It is quite ironic that in the bicentennial year, 1988, when many local governments are actually older than the Federal Parliament, we should be asking ourselves whether local government should be recognised within the Constitution. However, I acknowledge that whatever form of constitutional recognition may be recommended by the Constitutional Commission, it is important to strike a sensible balance as to the form of that recognition. We all know that local government operates under State legislation, and the Federal Government does not wish to see any changes in that regard. What we do want to see is that the work of local government, its contribution to economic and social policy development throughout the country, is recognised; that a rationalisation process that my Department is working on in conjunction with a number of other departments is implemented to avoid certain duplication of Federal, State and local government involvement in similar procedures-in other words that we rationalise some of the duplication.

We recognise that local government is the sector of government and public policy development closest to the people, and as such it does have the right to be recognised in the Constitution. As I say, we have to wait for the response of the Constitutional Commission. We all know what procedures must apply before any changes can be made to the Constitution. I believe the Constitutional Commission will consider very closely a number of representations that have been made by local government and other people in the community. I am very pleased to let members of the Senate know that the support for constitutional recognition seems to be coming from all parties. I have had letters from my National Party colleagues in Queensland. I believe I have had words of support from Senator Panizza. I have spoken to a number of my State Government colleagues in Victoria and Western Australia. I do hope, depending on what the Constitutional Commission finally recommends, that any approach that then goes to the people in the form of a referendum will be on a sensible, bipartisan basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of allegations in the European Parliament, reported on the radio program The World Today on Tuesday, that uranium that was mined in Australia is being shipped by the French firm Eurodiff to the United States of America, where it will be enriched by the West German firm Nukem to a weapons grade standard to be used in the reactor at Grenoble? I ask the Minister: Is this not in direct contravention of Australian safeguards arrangements? If not, why not? Will the Government inform the Senate of the results of investigations being carried out by the Australian Safeguards Office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the program The World Today, but the references made in that program--
—It would have the same degree of authenticity as most of the rest of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's programs.

—I did not quite hear what Senator Stone said, but it may not be that important. As I was saying, I did not hear The World Today program, but the allegations made in that program have been brought to my attention. All I can say about them is that last week in the Senate I answered two questions on allegations made about Australian uranium, the European Atomic Energy Commission (EURATOM), Nukem, and other things of that nature. The answer to Senator Wood's question is that we have obtained copies of the Der Spiegel magazine containing the articles on which it appears the reports are based, and we have translated those articles. From those reports it is fair to say, I think, that there seems to be an entanglement of assertions, which suggests, maybe, some confusion on the part of the reporter. We are looking at each of those things. It should be said that Der Spiegel magazine is not quite what you would call in the colloquial a tits and bums magazine, but it is somewhere between that and the quality Press. It brought to us the Hitler diaries--
—That is not parliamentary.
—It is a common colloquial expression for a type of periodical which I thought would be familiar to people in the Senate. I see Senator Stone nodding his head in affirmation of that point.

ANSWER.PARA: If it would not offend honourable senators opposite, I would say that it is not so much a down-market magazine or an up-market magazine; it is somewhere in the middle. It brought to us the celebrated Hitler diaries expose which fell a bit on its face. I do not say those things in order necessarily to denigrate the magazine, but so that comments in the Australian Press last week that it is a highly respected magazine are put into some focus. I do not know that that is a commonly held view. However, allegations have been made. We treat all allegations seriously and those allegations are being investigated. We treat all allegations so seriously that, after reading in the Australian Press that an Australian commentator has accused the Government of lying on this matter, I intend to contact the person concerned in order to obtain from that individual the detail of his allegation so that that can also be investigated.

In January and February Der Spiegel published a series of articles alleging things similar to what has been contained in Senator Wood's question. I think I said last week that our advice-certainly, it is my advice-is that nothing has happened which offends against the Australian safeguards regime with respect to that series of allegations. As I said earlier, The World Today report seems to be based on Der Spiegel. In my second answer on, I think, Thursday of last week, when I drew attention to an interjection by Senator Peter Baume to my Wednesday question, I promised that a report would be given by Minister Kerin after all the allegations have been properly itemised, documented and investigated and we are in a position to reply. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I remind the Minister that my question was about allegations in the European Parliament, not about allegations in Der Spiegel magazine. The allegations were made by members of the European Parliament, not by reporters with Der Spiegel. Also, my question related to a report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program The World Today. The material in that program included material that was not in Der Spiegel magazine. I specifically asked the Minister about uranium mined in Australia going to the United States for reprocessing to weapons grade uranium. If the Minister needs to explain the tangled web of reflagging--
—Order! This must be a question, not an elaboration.

—It is a question. Can the Minister confirm that it was a shipment of uranium that was mined in this country, no matter what flag it was wearing at the time? Was it Australian uranium that the French firm Eurodiff was sending to the United States to be reprocessed into weapons grade uranium to be used in the reactor at Grenoble? —I may have omitted to say in my earlier answer that, from what I know, it appears to me that the allegations made in the European Parliament are related to what has been published in Der Spiegel. Nuclear material held under an Australian safeguards agreement cannot be enriched to more than 20 per cent without Australia's formal approval. This was not sought in the Grenoble case as Australia was not responsible for the uranium enriched at that research facility. I think that that might more specifically answer Senator Wood's supplementary question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister representing the Minister for Defence I seek leave to make a statement entitled `Government Defence Policy-a Progress Report', to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
A little over twelve months ago, I tabled in this House a White Paper which has set the course of development towards a self reliant defence posture until the end of the century.
Today I wish to report the progress we have made over the past year in making self-reliance a reality for Australia.
The White Paper committed this Government to develop a defence force which is carefully designed to meet the unique demands of Australia's strategic circumstances.
Australians of all shades of political opinion have welcomed the new clarity which the White Paper has brought to defence planning.
In particular they have welcomed the White Paper's affirmation that, with careful management, we can maintain a self-reliant defence posture at a reasonable and sustainable cost.

It is fundamental to this Government's defence policy that our defence posture must be affordable. Australia's security will not be enhanced by making grand plans which cannot be fulfilled. This has happened before-for example in 1976.

Our defence policy encompasses the largest capital investment program in Australia's peacetime history. But we can fund that program without continuous growth in defence spending, provided we manage the defence budget carefully.

We have proved that over the past year. Financial circumstances have been tough. After years of strong growth under the Hawke Government defence spending has been cut this year. But through innovative management we have kept the White Paper on track.

We had some confidence this could be achieved because the program-unlike the grandiose plans of our predecessors-is not based on unrealistically high funding expectations. Investment in new equipment is spread over 15 years and we have committed little more than half the funds likely to be available in that period.
The White Paper also recognised that it would be possible to make better use of the funds already available to defence by concentrating spending in areas of high priority.

Realistic planning and good management are fundamental to the White Paper program and realistic planning and good management have enabled it to survive the test of the last nine months virtually unscathed.

The Australian Defence Force is undergoing unprecedented changes at a number of levels. Each of the three Services is progressively being re-equipped with the most appropriate weaponry available as many of the programs outlined in the White Paper have begun in earnest. However, the White Paper program is about more than equipment; it is about the people who make up the Defence Force, the command of our forces, and their deployment. I will be saying more about this shortly.

It is our assessment that, in credible contingencies, operations in the sea-air gap to the north and north-west of Australia and the protection of the infrastructure in the north would be of prime importance. This would require the deployment of considerable forces in the area and in some cases could require operations further afield through our northern bases. Operations by the maritime, ground and air forces involved would require close co-ordination and extensive logistic support. In addition there would be a requirement for very close co-operation with the civil authorities.

The shift in emphasis in our defence effort northwards is a key element in the Government's defence policy. Two important decisions have been made which will give form and substance to this new direction.
First, the Government has decided to establish a Northern Command based at Darwin.

Northern Command, or Norcom as it will be called, will be the focal point for the co-ordination of peacetime activity and will provide the nucleus for the larger organisation which would need to be quickly put in place in the event of a defence emergency.

Norcom will be a subordinate formation of Land Command. It will be predominantly oriented towards the planning and conduct of land operations but will be jointly staffed. It will be commanded by a brigadier supported by a staff drawn from the present 7th Military District Headquarters in Darwin together with Navy and RAAF personnel.

Norcom's area of responsibility will include the Northern Territory and the Kimberley region of Western Australia together with adjacent waters. Army units in the Norcom area will come directly under Norcom and naval and air units will be available to support Norcom activities. Additional forces will be assigned from time to time if the need arises.
The new command should be operational by July this year.

These new arrangements demonstrate our commitment to the defence of our north as expressed in the White Paper. They put in place a joint operational headquarters capable of conducting low level operations and other peacetime tasks and capable of expansion in the event of escalation. They also will enhance the already close working relationship with the civil authorities and the civilian community. This relationship would be vital in the event of low-level conflict or major natural disaster.
The second important decision relating to the defence of the north is to conduct a major defence force exercise there next year based on the strategy outlined in the White Paper.

This exercise, named Kangaroo 89, will be the biggest military activity in Australia since the Second World War, and will be the first major defence force exercise based on the White Paper strategy. It will exercise the ability of the Defence Force to respond to widely dispersed low level threats. Land force activities will extend right across the north of Australia and maritime and air activities will extend from Australia's north-western maritime approaches to Torres Strait and the new air bases at Tindal in the Northern Territory and Derby in the north west.

More than 17,000 ground troops, supported by naval and air units, will participate. United States forces will make a major contribution by allowing us to exercise capabilities which shortly will be introduced into the Defence Force. For example, United States Black Hawke helicopters will provide the degree of mobility for our ground forces which we will acquire when our own Black Hawks become operational.

A significant aspect of the White Paper strategy which will be exercised in Kangaroo 89 will be the deployment of selected Army Reserve units of the 1st and 3rd Divisions in their new role of protecting vital northern installations.

While it will be a major event, exercise Kangaroo 89 will enable us to exercise only some of the many capabilities called for in the White Paper. These capabilities, some of which substantially exist and some of which we are in the process of development and refinement include intelligence and surveillance, strike and interdiction, enhanced maritime warfare and mine countermeasures capabilities, development of the Army's capability for dispersed operations, enhancing command, control and communication systems and streamlining administration and logistics.

The strategy of defence in depth gives priority to being able to mount operations capable of defeating enemy forces in our area of direct military interest. This means we must have forces capable of tracking and targeting an adversary, which can mount maritime and air operations in the sea-air gap to our north, and which can carry out offensive strike and interdiction missions. Our forces must have a comprehensive range of defensive capabilities-including air defence, mine counter-measures, and protection of coastal trade-and must embody mobile land forces able to defeat hostile incursions at remote locations.

Defence in depth gives priority to meeting credible levels of threat in our area of direct military interest. The strategic assessments in the White Paper analysis are still pertinent and remain the basis of our capability programs.

The strategy of defence in depth calls on the Defence Force to be deployable and effective in the most likely areas of operation. The challenge of operating in the north demands not only investment in appropriate equipment but the establishment of a facilities infrastructure. Equipment and support facilities are an integral part of a defence capability throughout the three defensive layers we are building.

The first important requirement for Australia's defence is to possess comprehensive intelligence about our region and a surveillance capacity to detect and track intruders in maritime approaches. The Government has assigned a high priority to the development of a network of operational over-the-horizon radars to enhance our ability to monitor the vast sea and air gap to our north.

The upgrade of the initial over-the-horizon radar installation at Alice Springs is well underway and due for completion in 1990 at a total cost of about $60m. The upgrade at Alice Springs will assist in project definition studies for a network of up to three radars, the first of which should become operational in the mid-1990s. Within the next few weeks an invitation to register interest in the development of the first operational radar will be issued to industry. The estimated cost of the entire project is $500m, and will involve Australian industry in design development and construction.

The development of the Australian defence satellite communications station at Geraldton is progressing to plan. The land for the station has been acquired and contracts are being let for the supply of services, the access road and other site related works. Construction work on the project itself is scheduled to start in September this year.

Competing tenders are currently being evaluated for modern electronic support systems for the Defence Force's P3C Orion long range maritime patrol and surveillance aircraft. The successful tenderer is expected to be announced early next year.

Our surveillance capability will be enhanced by the delivery of the Navy's new Seahawk helicopters, of which 16 have been ordered to equip our FFG-7 class guided missile frigates. The first of these aircraft has already flown in the United States and the first two Seahawks should be delivered to the RAN in November. This will enhance our flexibility for a range of maritime tasks apart from surveillance, as the Seahawks have significant anti-submarine warfare, and weapons targeting capabilities.

Our surveillance capabilities are also being enhanced by the development of towed acoustic arrays for our new submarines and surface ships. This development will add significantly to our capability for sub-surface surveillance of our maritime approaches. A request for tender has been issued for the full-scale engineering development of the arrays based on indigenous technology developed jointly by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and Australian industry. The full scope of the project is to design, manufacture and trial arrays for our new submarines.

The Government has also recognised the importance of mapping and charting for military operations and surveillance. Recently a contract valued at $18.7m was awarded for local construction of four inshore survey ships. We have also called for tenders for the manufacture of an Australian designed laser airborne depth sounder. Bathymetry services have been transferred from the Department of Administrative Services to the Navy.

Action has been taken in a number of areas to expand the deployment of our maritime patrol capabilities through co-operation with regional nations, particularly New Zealand. It has been agreed to increase the number of RAAF long range maritime patrol aircraft deployments in the South Pacific.

To complement these enhanced intelligence and surveillance capabilities there is a requirement for a naval/air capability to destroy enemy forces in our approaches and to protect focal points and shipping lanes. Our strike and interdiction capabilities have been strengthened through a number of significant steps.

The project with the highest profile has undoubtedly been the new submarine acquisition for which a contract was signed in June last year. The Australian Submarine Corporation will oversee the construction of six Kockums type 471 submarines at Port Adelaide. The establishment of construction facilities is already well underway and building of the first submarine should begin in 1989. The combat system should be fitted by 1992 and the vessel launched in 1994. The five other submarines will be launched in the years 1995-1999.

A number of contracts worth approximately $390m have been placed for such items as combat systems, weapons discharge equipment, propulsion systems, computer software and the sonar installation. This provides substantial opportunities for Australian industry involvement as over 70 per cent of the platform work and 45 per cent of the combat system work will be performed in Australia.

Another important component of the second layer will be the new ANZAC patrol frigates. This project has provided us with a valuable avenue for co-operation with New Zealand. We have signed a memorandum of understanding with New Zealand covering the purchase of a similar class of vessel for our navies. We will take eight of the vessels whilst New Zealand may purchase four.

Two Australian-based consortia with New Zealand partners have been formed, each in association with a ship designer, to tender for construction of the ships in Australia. The contract for construction will be let about the middle of next year with the first ship due for delivery in the mid-1990s.

An effective mine countermeasures force able to keep our major ports open and nearby ocean areas safe is a high priority for the Government. Trials of the two Australian built minehunting catamarans are proceeding and a decision on the purchase of further vessels will be made once trials are complete. A former Department of Transport vessel has been acquired to test the `craft of opportunity' minesweeping concept, using innovative Australian designed acoustic and magnetic sweeping equipment. Development work has also commenced for a mine warfare systems centre.

The level of protection afforded to our surface ships is being enhanced through the collaborative development with the United States of a ship defence system. This undertaking, known as Project Nulka, is drawing upon innovative, indigenous technologies from within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and Australian industry. A prime contract has been placed with a leading Australian electronics company with support from the Government's factories and DSTO.

This is consistent with the Government's policy of expanding the role of Australian industry in such undertakings. Associated electronics work in the United States is providing an avenue for valuable technology transfers through joint project arrangements.

In order to enhance our ability to deploy our maritime forces in northern and north western strategic areas, the Government has taken steps towards the creation of a genuine two ocean navy. Our planning is for half of our major surface combatants and submarine forces as well as mine countermeasure vessels and an afloat support ship to be based in Western Australia by the turn of the century.

A number of developments have already taken place at HMAS Stirling, near Perth, including the home porting of the submarine HMAS Oxley in September last year. At present there are two destroyers, a hydrographic ship and two Fremantle class patrol boats also based at Stirling. A third destroyer will be home ported in Western Australia next year.

Late last year an agreement was reached with the Western Australian Government jointly to support a new marine facility at nearby Jervoise Bay which will include a shiplift capability, to be enhanced as operations of naval vessels in the west increase.

Broad planning has been completed for a two stage development of HMAS Stirling which will progressively cater for half the fleet's basing requirements. Comprehensive studies are also underway into the viability of a relocation of the eastern fleet base from Sydney Harbour to Jervis Bay. The first stage of the studies is an environmental impact statement.

The major airborne component of our air defence capability is the acquisition of the F/A-18s. At present activation of Hornet operational squadrons is proceeding smoothly, with 38 aircraft delivered so far. Two squadrons and an operational conversion unit have been established at RAAF Base Williamtown. However, there is a lag of five aircraft in the delivery timetable and remedial action is underway.

Project definition work for the upgrade of the avionics of our F-111s is now complete. Proposals to implement the major components of the update, the avionics and the avionics test equipment, will be considered next financial year.

Sixty-seven PC9/A pilot training aircraft are being acquired as an eventual replacement for the present CT4 airtrainers. The first two aircraft from the Australian production line were accepted from Hawker De Havilland in December last year.
As local production at Bankstown expands, so too will the level of Australian manufactured components used in the aircraft; the 21st and later aircraft will be almost entirely produced in Australia.

The operations of our air defence aircraft, strike and interdiction aircraft and our surveillance aircraft are to be enhanced through the development of our northern airfields' infrastructure. The major works at Tindal are progressing on schedule and within budget. Over 75 per cent of the works have already been completed and RAAF personnel have begun to man the base, with a planned date for the commencement of F/A-18 basing in October this year.

The airfield and associated works near Derby were completed in December last year and planning is proceeding for other support works to further enhance the operational capabilities of this bare base airfield. The Government expects to be able to fund this in the 1989-90 budget year.

Investigations have also commenced into a Cape York Peninsula airfield site through joint consultative arrangements with the Queensland Government. Present planning is for work to begin in the 1990-91 financial year subject to the results of an environmental impact study.

The final element of the Government's defence strategy calls for a flexible ground force, with air and naval support, able to react to an enemy incursion and to protect dispersed population centres and infrastructure. The restructuring of our ground forces to meet credible contingencies has progressed well. An Army force structure based on the 1st Division, two Reserve Divisions and training and logistic commands has been retained.

The shift in the focus of Army operations northwards has been particularly apparent over the past 12 months. Planning for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to move from Holsworthy to Darwin is well advanced and the regiment should be installed in its new barracks by the end of 1992. Appropriate training areas are also being acquired. An examination of the implications of relocating a brigade to the north is also underway, with a study of the strategic, operational, logistic and personnel implications scheduled for completion later this year.

The emphasis on ground based surveillance has continued with the development of the regional force surveillance units in the north. Norforce participated with the 2nd Cavalry Regiment in exercises in the Northern Territory late in 1987. New regional force surveillance unit depots are planned and the raising of two new companies by 51 Far North Queensland Regiment next year will enable it to increase its presence in the Gulf of Carpentaria and Torres Strait regions.

To ensure that we get the most appropriate mobility for our forces, a selected range of wheeled armoured vehicles for possible use by the 2nd Cavalry Regiment will commence evaluation trials under northern conditions next year.

The introduction into service of 39 Black Hawk battlefield helicopters is progressing well, with the delivery of the first Australian assembled helicopters scheduled for April. The acquisition of the Black Hawks will contribute significantly to the combat power of the Army's operational deployment force. This capability should be fully operational within the target period of five years and full Army manning is likely to be achieved by 1993-94.

The role of the Reserves has been enhanced through the introduction of call out legislation last year. The Army Reserve is now being developed as an integral part of the force rather than a component of its expansion base. This process, which has been achieved within the 26,000 manpower ceiling detailed in the White Paper, is almost complete. The reorganisation has provided the Army Reserve with a sense of purpose which is reflected in improved morale and reduced wastage.
Other equipment projects, principally for the Army, include new small arms, 105mm guns, bridging, all-terrain cranes, medium trucks and radios.
Other aspects of defence planning are being redirected in the light of our new policy orientation.

A major review of Defence Force command and control arrangements was carried out last year. It concluded that the present system of joint force commanders should be further developed in several important directions. I will give details of these changes and make public a declassified version of this review in the near future.

The new military manpower system referred to in the White Paper has been introduced to give the Services a stable trained force and supplementation of the training force to match fluctuating separation rates.
Defence property holdings have been reviewed, and those not required for efficient operations will be disposed of.

I have already mentioned Australian industry's involvement in several key defence equipment projects. Australian industry involvement in the supply, repair and maintenance of Defence Force stores and equipment has been increased dramatically under this Government.

This comprehensive Australian industry involvement in defence procurement is a direct consequence of the Government's commitment to defence self-reliance. It is also a vindication of the Government's wider economic policies and initiatives. For example, our ability to source over two thirds by value of the submarine and ANZAC ship projects in Australia is due in large part to Australian industry's increasing ability to compete for work in the international market place.

The Government also has moved to realise the potential of an increasingly competitive Australian defence industry to generate export income. In late 1986 I announced a series of practical measures to foster Australian defence exports. These measures were based in part on preliminary recommendations by my ministerial consultant, Mr Bob Cooksey. I also took up Mr Cooksey's suggestion that current defence export guidelines could be revised to enable a better balance of Australian commercial, defence and international interests in the defence export area.

The Government has recently agreed to a series of principles to guide detailed revision of existing defence export guidelines. The Government also agreed to streamline existing cumbersome administrative arrangements. Substantial work is required to finalise the new arrangements which are to be in place by May this year.
The Government recognised in the White Paper that the highly skilled and dedicated members of the Defence Force are our most valuable defence resource.
The Opposition said a lot about our defence personnel policies, but they have offered no solutions to the undoubted difficulties the ADF faces in keeping highly-skilled people.

This Government has given unprecedented attention to this issue. My colleague Mrs Kelly has been appointed to undertake a thorough overhaul of defence personnel issues, and her work in this area is both very important and very complex. Anyone who believes that the solutions in this area are simple does not understand the problem.
We have allocated substantial funds to rectify deficiencies in the personnel area which have been building up over many years.

The most widespread and justified complaint by service personnel relates to the quality of the defence housing stock. The Government recognised this deficiency by establishing the Defence Housing Authority, which began operation on 1 January this year. The Government is committed to spending $750m on upgrading existing houses or acquiring new houses over a 10 year period.

The Government also is committed to improving living conditions for single people in the Defence Force. A $57m project will begin this year to upgrade existing barracks accommodation by the provision of 4,500 single rooms.
The question of appropriate salaries and allowances for members of the Defence Force has been addressed by the independent tribunal established by the Government.

The tribunal has now determined 17 Defence Force remuneration cases, four of which were national wage case flow-on increases. These proceedings have all led to Defence Force pay or allowances increases within the national wage case principles, and include the second tier increase agreed with the Commonwealth and which the Defence Force achieved on its own merits. The Defence Force Renumeration Tribunal is serving its purpose well.
None of these achievements could have been realised without particularly adept resource management.

When considering the terms of reference which should be given to Paul Dibb for his review of defence force capabilities, the Government recognised that financial realism would be the key to successful implementation of his recommendations.

The evidence for this was clear for all to see: the Fraser Government's Afghanistan debacle had left the Defence Force confused and demoralised, and financial irresponsibility was the achilles heel of the 1976 White Paper.

The firm foundation for military strength is economic strength. No matter how high it is on the Government's list of priorities, defence-in peacetime-cannot be insulated from economic realities. When the full extent of the measures which would be required to revitalise the economy became apparent, the Government had no hesitation in deciding that defence, along with other important programs such as education, health and welfare, should contribute to economic recovery.

In principle, there was nothing new or extraordinary about this: Similar action had been taken twice under governments led by Malcolm Fraser. However, in the past, the absence of a coherent set of priorities within the defence program had made the management of austerity next to impossible. The existence of the White Paper meant that, on this occasion, austerity was not only manageable but, in the final outcome, it has proved beneficial. It has driven us to find ways of meeting our total objectives at less cost than originally envisaged.

The realisation of substantial economies within the defence portfolio was an integral part of the White Paper strategy. Even before the White Paper was prepared, work had begun on the restructuring of the defence factories and dockyards. Williamstown Naval Dockyard in Melbourne, once a substantial burden on the defence appropriation, has now been sold to a private consortium for $100m without diminishing our vital shipbuilding capability.

In October last year the Government Aircraft Factories in Melbourne were placed on a more commercial footing when they began operations as a government owned company, known as Aerospace Technologies of Australia.

Streamlining of other factories and facilities is continuing with an emphasis on making their operations more commercially orientated. Significant productivity programs are being put in place, particularly at Garden Island Dockyard.

More recently, the Government has instituted a review of defence logistics-an area which accounts for more than 30 per cent of the defence budget and employs 30,000 people. I am confident that it will be possible to achieve substantial savings; efficiency improvements already identified amount to over $100m a year.
Honourable members might be interested in some examples of improvements that are being introduced.

We have approved changes to the defence contacting organisation and contracting procedures to simplify procurement. We are looking at streamlining our decision-making arrangements for purchasing stores and are planning to make substantial reductions in administrative processes. We have looked at the size of the defence inventory, and found that many items have not been used for years. We are getting rid of those which we no longer need. We are introducing ways of making our procurement and stock distribution systems run faster-which will lead to substantial reductions in expenditure and infrastructure.

Other means of improving the efficiency and productivity of defence logistics also are being pursued. We are now placing major emphasis on the use of local management and commercial infrastructure in support of the Defence Force. For example, we are examining prospects for a much closer relationship with the transport industry in the management and running of defence commercial vehicles.

Apart from these specific reviews, the whole structure of the Department is being streamlined to cut out waste and duplication, to produce a less hierarchical and more efficient structure. This is the most radical restructuring of the defence organisation, and of attitudes within it, since the Barnard reorganisation in 1973-75.

Government policy requires Defence to shed 3.75 per cent of its civilian staff by the end of June 1990. Savings of 3 per cent-that is 80 per cent of the target-have already been made. Last year civilian staffing was reduced by more than 1300. I should stress that these were balanced cuts spread across the defence spectrum. For example, 16 senior executive service positions have been abolished since July 1986. I expect to continue reducing civilian staff by at least one per cent a year over the next five years.
Those who see the grey-suited mandarins of Russell Hill as regiments of Sir Humphreys should realise that in fact they are some of the toughest and brightest managers in the country.

I do not believe we have yet reached the bottom of this barrel. It is the Government's aim not only to achieve the White Paper's objectives but to achieve them with as little cost to the taxpayer as possible. There is no merit in bringing down big defence budgets; the merit lies in what is achieved with the money. The Government will continue to seek savings through increased efficiency within the defence portfolio until it is satisfied that every dollar allocated is making an effective contribution to defence preparedness.

At this stage it is difficult to quantify the overall savings which will flow from the large number of efficiency and restructuring programs which have been implemented or are being developed but I am confident that, if all planned savings are realised, about $200m a year can be freed to fund the high priority programs identified in the White Paper.

Two hundred million dollars a year over the life of the White Paper program adds up to $3b. When I remind honourable members that the target cost of the ANZAC ship project is $3.5billion, it is readily apparent how significant these savings are.

The White Paper objectives can be achieved without continuous real growth in the defence appropriation, provided the savings which can be obtained through increased efficiency are realised and the program continues to be managed effectively.

Finally I would like to acknowledge the dedication and professionalism of the men and women of the ADF who are responding to the challenges of the White Paper to build the Defence Force we need to make self-reliance a reality, and guarantee Australia's security into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that we have before us this afternoon from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) continues the practice of defence by deception which has been practised by this Government. I want to develop the theme of the deception that is perpetrated by this Minister and I also want to talk about the politicisation of the Department of Defence, because never in my time have I seen the Defence Department prostituted for political aims in the way it has been under Minister Beazley. The prospect of defence by deception horrifies all of those on the Opposition side. We have the technique of the grandiose statement; we have the statement this afternoon which amounts to nothing-a statement written by two or three civilians in the Department of Defence, and the Minister did not contribute a word to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Before that, some weeks ago, we had a similar statement put out purely for public relations reasons. We have had the development of the pseudo-authoritative reports on defence, the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities of two or three years ago, the White Paper of last year and the Cooksey Review of Australia's Defence Co-operation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment which, curiously enough, has never been released. Why has not the Cooksey report been released? Maybe now that the New South Wales election is over some of the recommendations that I presume Mr Cooksey made about shutting down inefficient defence facilities in New South Wales can be released to the Australian public.

All this business of defence by deception counts for nought. It does not fool any potential adversaries of Australia and it certainly does not fool the Opposition. We have the situation in which a Defence Minister is in the same position with respect to public esteem as Mr Hawke was before the Adelaide by-election. Just as Mr Hawke did not have the credentials to sustain that high reputation, nor has Mr Beazley. The reality is that the Beazley administration of the Department of Defence has reduced Australia to a situation where we have less capability in the Australian defence forces than at any time in my life. One point is that the resignation rates for the defence forces are at record levels. Over half the members of the Australian Defence Force have voted with their feet since this Labor Government came to power. I want to come back to that later because the loss of personnel that we have suffered has destroyed the capability of the Australian defence forces for over a generation.

We now have a catastrophic situation as a consequence of these resignations. Whose fault was it? It was the fault of Mr Scholes and Mr Beazley-and more particularly Mr Beazley. The official figures put out by the Department show that declining resignation rates turned round in 1983. For the last five years they have been going up in a very steep trend line. It crossed, in 1984-85, the long term resignation rate.
