In the current figures, the long term resignation rate has been increased by the fact that it now incorporates as an average the high resignation rates of the last five years. So the situation in real statistical terms is worse than it appears at present. I will come to resignation rates in a bit more detail later in my speech.

What the Labor Party did to protect the Minister was a cynical and almost cannabalistic act to one of its own members. The Australian Labor Party happens to be particularly bankrupt for successors. Mr Hawke thinks of Mr Keating. Everyone in politics knows that Mr Keating has as much chance as any other undertaker of being elected as Prime Minister. Quite simply, he is unelectable. Mr Hawke knows this too. He sees Mr Beazley as one of the potential candidates. So Mr Hawke, probably Senator Button and a few of the others got together after the last election. They saw the disaster that was befalling them with the defence forces and the way it would impact on the career of Mr Beazley. So, very cynically, they isolated Mr Beazley from the problem.

They found a sacrificial lamb in Ms Ros Kelly. They said, `Ms Ros Kelly, would you like to be a Minister?'. Her vanity overcame her and she said, `Yes, I would love to be a Minister'. They said, `Good, you can be the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel'. From the moment she put her hand out for the Queen's shilling and signed on as a Minister she has become the source and the reason for the high resignation rates. The Senate knows very well that I carry no brief for Ms Kelly. I think her incompetence is manifest but I have a great sympathy for the way she has been made a sacrificial lamb for the shortcomings of Mr Beazley, in such a cynical way by the Labor Party.

The second point I mentioned was the politicisation of the Department of Defence. In my experience this is absolutely without parallel. It must horrify my colleague Senator Stone, who is imbued with the high ideals of objectivity of the Public Service. This politicisation takes two forms: first, with the awarding of contracts; and, secondly, with personnel in the Department of Defence. What we are seeing on the award of contracts is pork-barrelling on a scale that has never before been equalled. I shall give the Senate several examples. The submarine training facility which is due to be commissioned this month in Perth is something to which I will not receive an invitation and I doubt very much whether many of my colleagues on the Opposition side will. It is a very fine facility but it should never have been in Perth. There is no reason for its being there. All the submarine and naval training facilities are on the east coast. If one talks to senior naval officers, one finds that, in a very small navy such as the Royal Australian Navy, one of the complaints they make is about the increased expenditure arising from the dispersion of training facilities. The Royal Australian Navy is so small that there is a real argument for consolidation of training facilities, having them all close together in the one geographical position. But no, to pork-barrel the Western Australian Labor electorate, the submarine training facility has been built in the west. The ship lift facility is being built in Perth at Jervoise Bay-again in a pork-barrelling exercise. We had the award to Australian Shipbuilding Industries (WA) Pty Ltd of the Pacific patrol boats-a design which has proved to be quite inferior. Those of us who took an interest knew that at the time, but the contract was awarded in the face of other good designs around the country on the basis of pork-barrelling for Western Australia.

While I am discussing the Pacific patrol boat contract, I would like to reflect for a moment on the failure of this Government to coordinate the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The animosity between Mr Hayden and Mr Beazley is legendary. They do not talk to one another. What is even worse, the two departments do not talk to one another. Thus, we have different conceptual goals pursued by the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Mr Hayden goes off to quasi-communist, revolutionary regimes in southern Africa and gives them $10m here and $20m there, adding up to $100m, while Mr Beazley cannot get money to support people in our region-in the South Pacific, the Philippines and Indonesia-with defence cooperation programs which are so vital to our regional security. One other point is that when we gave these countries the patrol boats we did not look at the cost of running them. It did not occur to Mr Beazley that, in one particular case, the award of a patrol boat to a small Pacific nation cost more in fuel in one year than the entire gross domestic product of that state.

Let us look at other examples of pork-barrelling. Let us look at what happened in Adelaide. We all knew that the award of the submarine contract to Adelaide was a pork-barrelling exercise. We lacked proof until Mr Michael Jerome Young resigned. When Mr Young resigned all his senior Cabinet colleagues came out and said, `Well, that is terrible for Mick to go; he got us the submarine contract in Adelaide'. Those of us who knew anything about the matter knew that South Australia lacked the technical heavy engineering resources to do the job and all the nonsense put out by Premier Bannon claiming that Adelaide would win the contract because of its good industrial relations record was entirely false. The only two shipbuilders that ever existed in South Australia closed down some years ago because of strikes and union problems. Yet the reason that was given for the awarding of that contract to Adelaide was that its industrial relations would be so good.

Then we come to the whole concept of the two-ocean navy. It is certainly true that Australia must maintain a military presence in both the Indian and Pacific oceans. But with such a small navy as ours, with only 12 surface ships, of which probably no more than nine are serviceable at any one time, it is a nonsense to talk about developing a facility on the west coast which has permanently-based people. We must have facilities on the east and west coasts, but the concept should be that these are facilities that can be activated in an emergency. They should be similar to the bare base facilities that we have at Derby and Learmonth for the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) because the political situation changes. There are times when we will need to deploy ships in the Indian Ocean; there are times when we will need to deploy them in the South Pacific region. We should have the flexibility to concentrate our resources in the area.

A secondary very important consideration is the need, where you have very small forces, to be able to aggregate them for training. The Navy can do no effective training if half its resources are on the east coast and half are on the west coast. Politicisation of the award of contracts has now reached a degree we have never seen before.

The second point I want to turn to is the politicisation of the Department of Defence. That is probably not a very precise description because it is not politicisation by party politics. It is rather the removal of all inquiring minds of the civilian component of the Department of Defence. I think of one of my old adversaries, one of the senior personnel in the Department, Mr Wrigley. I do not know what Mr Wrigley's politics were. Obviously he had an inquiring mind, obviously he was a person who would not be pushed around; who asked why such and such a thing was being done. From innumerable contests at Estimates committees I found him a very difficult person to deal with. He was removed-sent as director of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Now, all senior executive officers of the Department of Defence with service greater than three years have been removed. Mr Woods, the Secretary, has purged the Department of anyone who will oppose or come up with any critical view of what the Minister wants in the Department. I find that quite a frightening proposition. It flies in the face of the argument that the civilian component of the Department of Defence, the senior officers, are there on a long-term basis to provide continuity and stability.

What are the consequences of all this? The consequences are very simple and very stark. Never in my lifetime has the Australian Defence Force been weaker than it is at the moment. It has record resignation rates and it has morale at rock bottom, particularly in the Navy and the Air Force. It is a little better in the Army but not much. More than half the members of the Australian Defence Force have left since Labor came into office. A consequence of this today is that we have lost our capability to use the defence forces in the limited roles we could before, but most importantly we have lost it for a generation ahead. It is not only the raw numbers we have lost; we have lost trained and experienced people. One cannot train a ship's captain by putting him through a ship handling school and in 18 months or two years putting him in command. One cannot train a company commander or battalion commander in the same period. Least of all can one train a fighter pilot or a strike pilot in anything under about 1,000 flying hours, something like eight to 10 years. Those are the people the Australian Labor Party has driven out of the Australian Defence Force.

I have never seen morale worse in the Navy. I think the fact that in a recent period of three months five ships captains resigned after they had command speaks for itself. Career naval officers crave command. It is the high point of their careers, to command one of the major ships of the Australian Navy. It has not been my experience that any naval officer, once he has achieved command, has not gone on from captain to commodore and higher-most of them go on to rear-admiral. In recent months five resigned after they exercised command. Why are they doing this? They are doing this because their conditions of service are so poor. They know their professional abilities are not recognised by the Government. They know their professional capabilities are not developed. They have no air power at sea. They have no aircraft carrier. They cannot operate beyond the limits of the Australian coastline, otherwise they will be destroyed. They have no amphibious capability. Last year they had humiliation, as professionals, when they were asked to go to Fiji. They responded immediately with the best of their resources, but they had to take Landrovers in rowing boats from Norfolk Island to put them aboard HMAS Tobruk. No heavy landing craft could be deployed for that amphibious force that went to Fiji.

We come to the Air Force. The purpose of the Air Force is to fly aircraft. Aircraft cannot be flown without pilots. There are about 22,500 personnel in the Air Force. From information given to me in Estimates committees over the years, of that 22,500 approximately 770 are pilots. The number of active pilot positions in the Air Force is about 480, although I suspect that number has been considerably reduced with regard to their nominal roles by the creative accounting that the Minister has used to cover up the deficiencies. Approximately 420 to 500 positions in the Air Force require pilots to fly aircraft. Approximately another 80 pilots are required for non-flying positions.

Last year the Air Force lost 110 pilots. Already this financial year it has lost 117 pilots, and the departmental estimate alone is that this year it will lose 130. So, in 24 months it will have lost 240 pilots. The pilot loss should be balanced against the long term loss rate of pilots from the RAAF over 20 years of 42 a year. Again, the Minister and the Department are fudging the figures. They say that the long term loss rate is 47 pilots a year. The long term loss rate has gone up from 42 to 47 because of the loss of 110 pilots last year which have been included in the mathematics. However, let us not quibble about that. Essentially the Air Force has lost half of its pilots at the present time.

The pilots being lost are not those who have just graduated from Pearce with their wings. The pilots who are leaving are those who have been in the Air Force for about 10 years. They have flown well over 1,000 hours, and have each cost this country somewhere between $4m and $8m to train. Their experience cannot be bought in the facile way in which the Ministers say we will train our way out of it. We cannot replace those people with eight to 10 years experience until we train a new bunch. That will take eight to 10 years and probably longer because, as the RAAF is so critically short of pilots, it does not have the number of flying instructors it needs. Even if there were a full complement of flying instructors, they could train, going full bore, only 65 pilots a year. But the pilots are leaving at twice that rate.

Honourable senators should not believe any of the talk that these pilots are being bought with money. There has always been a huge disparity between what the airlines pay and what the RAAF pays. Yet we have never had the problem that we have today. We have the problem today purely because the Government treats pilots with contempt. The pilots know that the job they are doing is not appreciated by the Government, and is not appreciated by the Australian community. So, sure, the pilots are going to Qantas Airways Ltd, Singapore Airlines Ltd and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. For that, not only the Defence Minister but also the Treasurer have something to answer for.

All the scare talk about rapacious taxes and superannuation is having a twofold effect. First, captains in the airline industry who are close to retirement are going while they can still get something from the superannuation to which they have contributed. That is increasing the employment opportunities for RAAF pilots. The second factor is the punitive taxation rates that apply in Australia. I am talking about pilots who have been in the RAAF for 10 years, who have 1,000 hours or more experience. They can go into command positions with a company like Cathay Pacific on a salary of $90,000 a year. However, instead of paying 50.25 per cent income tax, they pay 19 per cent. The Treasurer has compounded the problem with the way he has introduced cripplingly high taxation rates.

What is the consequence of the loss of pilots? The consequence is staggering. There is only one operational fighter squadron in Australia today: 75 Squadron in Darwin. A fighter squadron should have a complement of 18 pilots. Today 75 Squadron has, and has had for months, seven pilots.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many aircraft?

—It has 18 serviceable aircraft. For the first time Australia has a Mirage squadron with more serviceable aircraft than it has pilots to fly them. Usually it is the other way around, with a hangar full of unserviceable Mirages. Those seven pilots include the Executive Officer and the Commanding Officer. In practical terms, if Australia were faced with an emergency, this squadron that guards the portals of Australia could task two pilots on duty around the clock, giving it an endurance of three days. That is what the Australian Labor Party has done for Australia. That is what pacifists, such as Senator McMullan and the anti-Vietnam protesters, regard as an adequate defence policy for Australia. They have reduced us to a position from which we simply cannot recover for another decade.

SPEECH.PARA: Manning strengths in other squadrons have been reduced. Instead of there being 18 in the FA18 squadrons that are being formed, they are down to 12 pilots. We will have great difficulty manning the FA18 squadrons. Like the Leopard tanks which are in hangars, we will have aircraft in hangars because there will not be pilots to fly them. At best, we have seven crews for the maritime reconnaissance squadrons and, again, 10 aircraft in them. I emphasise that we cannot recover from this situation in a few years. It will take a generation to get back from it. The reason for it is this Government's bungling incompetence. The reason is its lack of concern for human beings. People are important, but the men and women of the Australian Defence Force are not valued by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Ministry or this Government. The service men and women of Australia know that they are held in such low esteem by the Government and they are going because they will not put up with it.

Money is not the key to satisfaction for those in the Services. The satisfaction comes from knowing that they are doing an important job; a job which is quite without parallel in the Australian community; a job that is totally distinctive from any other in the Public Service or private industry. They want simple recognition-no more than that-from the government of the day that what they do is important and valued. Since they are not getting it, they are leaving. They look at the great changes that have taken place in their conditions of service, the way they have had to fight tooth and nail for changes to their allowances and the way allowances such as the submarine allowance and the flying allowance have been delayed for years. The submarine allowance came through eventually, but only a month ago an interim decision was handed down on the flying allowance, although it has been in the pipeline for years. There is the business of removal expenses. It is not uncommon for service personnel to live in 17 or 18 different homes-perhaps Senator McLean will contribute to this-in 14 or 15 years. A lot of that is unnecessary, but it all occasions service personnel an expense. It probably costs them $2,000 or $3,000 every time they move, but we never see any recognition from the Government or the offer of an adequate return for the inevitable costs that those service men and women face from moving from Holsworthy to Lavarack, or whatever. The key to the problems we have in defence cannot be covered by papers such as that brought down by Mr Beazley today. Until this Government recognises the fact that the importance of the morale of the men and women in the Defence Force is the key to having a defence capability, we will face this incredible haemorrhage from which we are suffering.

Another point I want to deal with in relation to resignations concerns the fact that nothing was done in the Department. There has been an official graph from the Department on resignation rates and there are two points I wish to make about it. Firstly, the Australian defence forces are facing the highest gross loss of numbers ever and, secondly, we are losing critical people-the battalion commanders, the company commanders, ships captains and pilots-at a record rate. When one asks the Minister, the Secretary to the Department, the Chief of Defence Force and anyone associated with defence who detected the fact that the graph had turned around at the end of 1982-83, and what action was taken, one finds that nothing at all was done; they just monitored the situation. They looked at the monthly figures with eyes that did not see. Even when the line crossed the long term trend rate, which was way below what it is today, no-one did anything. The alarm bells did not ring; they just muddled on hoping that it would get better. That is absolutely inexcusable.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago was that?

—It has been five years. For five years the Government sat on its hands and looked out the window. More than that, no-one said, `Listen, gross numbers are one thing, but essential people are another. What is happening with this massive resignation of pilots? What is happening with the loss of battalion commanders and ship captains?'. No-one went to that point, which anyone with the most elementary intelligence should have thought of. I go back to news release No. 38/88 by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), which came out earlier this month, in which she recognised that no-one had made a critical analysis of loss rates in the Services. I find that quite unbelievable. Ms Kelly said:

SPEECH.PARA: At present, separations are given as a single percentage figure, which is not specific enough to pinpoint where our problems lie in retaining experienced personnel in the Defence Force. In fact, it tends to mask the areas where we are experiencing problems.

She patted herself on the back. Obviously she would not have thought of that; someone else would have done so. It just happens to be five years too late and, in one sense, it is 10 years too late because we cannot correct the problems that are there. That is the background against which Mr Beazley's public relations exercise has to be evaluated. Nothing in this progress report deals with the fundamental problems with Australian defence.

I do not have time to go through the report seriatim, but there is one point on which I wish to comment. Right at the start, the Minister talked about the creation of a Northern Command, or Norcom. The Minister loves toys and jargon. Norcom is an utterly wrong concept. When the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was in Darwin a couple of weeks ago, all of us, irrespective of our party, were horrified to hear of this proposal. In fact, we did not believe that it would happen. The Minister has set up a Northern Command which will be commanded by a brigadier. But that is irrelevant; the important thing is that this Northern Command, to deal with the Northern Territory and the sea and the air around it, will be an Army command-it will be a development of the land force operations. Nothing could be more stupid than that.

In the north the Army is the minor force; it is a very small force. Admittedly, it has a full colonel, but I think that the members of the permanent army in the north probably number 50 at the most. The Air Force is the biggest unit up there; it is a very big operation at Darwin and it will be bigger when it is at Tindal. The Navy also has a sizeable presence there under a captain with the patrol boat facility. All the activities that are involved, in an operational sense, in the north involve both the Air Force and the Navy. They are the important services. Now we have this fatuous scheme to put in a brigadier to coordinate the whole thing. It is not a joint force concept, with which I would have no quarrel. If it were a joint force structure, which rotated between the Services it would be one thing; but to put the Army, as the junior service, in this theatre strikes at the heart of morale in the other Services. That, more than anything else, typifies the lack of depth of perception in the present Minister and the way he handles his Ministry.

We are now defenceless. We will never get out of it while we have a Minister who resorts to a public relations machine to try to deceive the Australian public as to the gross deficiencies in his command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can agree with some of the points that Senator MacGibbon has made, but I feel it is important to put a different perspective into this debate on the defence paper. I appreciate, basically, the drift of the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the Defence White Paper, except for the enormous contradiction that is inherent in both those documents. They talk about Australia's self-reliant defence capabilities being within the framework of an alliance with the United States of America. To me, that is a contradiction in terms. How can we be self-reliant and independent in our defence thinking if we are tied in with one of the major superpowers, if we buy most of our equipment to suit the superpower's needs rather than our own and if we continue with very expensive joint exercises which, again, suit the requirements of the United States military command rather than the real defence needs of Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: I think that to talk of independence and self-reliance is good, but it must be pointed out that the statements of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) are absolutely contradictory. We cannot be independent while we are tied in with that alliance. I am not arguing for an isolationist position for Australia. I believe that we need to have good relationships with our neighbours and that we need to have some sort of defence co-operation with the other partner in the ANZUS Treaty, that is, New Zealand. We need to be co-operating closely with the New Zealand Government so that there is a feeling of security in this region. However, we do not make ourselves more secure by being tied in to an alliance with the United States when, in fact, we are doing the dirty work for the United States in making sure that we provide all of the intelligence gathering operations it needs for its military operations, whether they be nuclear or conventional, interventionist or genuinely defence. I think that we should have no part in that whatsoever. It is time that we really took very seriously this notion of independent self-defence capability.

For too long we have had a notion of grovel- ling subservience to the United States. For too long successive Australian governments have allowed Australia to be used. There is a lot of argument in Australia about how much money we should be spending on defence. We have just heard Senator MacGibbon say that we are not able to defend ourselves. I believe that, if we spent our defence dollars more wisely and really looked at the genuine defence of Australia rather than buying the long-range offensive weapons systems which suit the military purposes of the United States but which have nothing to do with the defence of Australia, our defence dollars would go a long way further and we would also be proceeding towards independence.

This bicentennial year is very embarrassing to some people because we have not yet acknowledged the Aboriginal people's prior claims to this land. At least the Australian Government has now done that officially, but the Australian people have a lot of catching up to do in that regard. Perhaps it is due to the fact that it is 200 years since non-Aboriginal people invaded this country that we are still beset with an invasion paranoia. This is something that is very deeply rooted in the Australian psyche and something that I think we need to eradicate, because we are not about to be invaded. Even people in the Defence Department acknowledge that generally. However, the Australian people still have this very strong invasion paranoia which is actually fed by the Cold War warriors and the sorts of people who organised the `red orchestra' conference that was held in Melbourne over the weekend.

What I find really disturbing in this latest paper from the Minister is that security is still viewed only in terms of military hardware and the joint war games that we play with our allies. We have heard a great deal about all the equipment we are to buy from the United States in the years ahead. It is worth making the point that these purchases contribute a great deal to our trade imbalance. I note too the increase in the price of the Hornets referred to recently. Although they were costed at $2.43 billion in 1981, they are now likely to cost $5.5 billion by the time the last aircraft is delivered in May 1990. That is hardly healthy for our balance of payments.

In the Asia-Pacific region security can chiefly be measured in economic terms. I believe that it is a grave error to continue this reliance on military hardware rather than considering the real security needs in this region, which invariably underlie the causes of war in the second half of the twentieth century. There was a very interesting article in the Weekend Australian last Saturday about wars in today's world. I have worked out that only 15 per cent of wars fought since 1945 have involved one country actually declaring war and invading another country while only one war has been fought in the First World-that is, if we count the crushing of the Hungarian people by the Soviet Union in 1956 as a war. Yet the Australian people remain obsessed by scenarios of invasion whipped up by the Cold War warriors. We have to realise that the nature of modern warfare has changed and that most of the wars that are taking place around the globe at the moment-and there are anything up to 40 conflicts raging right now; so we can hardly call our world peaceful-are to do with wars of liberation, internal conflicts or repression by oppressive regimes keeping their own people under the thumb.

Sadly, there is still no reference in the Minister's statement to avoiding the conditions that make for wars or ways in which Australia can strengthen conflict resolution mechanisms at the international level. I believe that this is where we should be putting a lot of our energies. Australia could have a very real role as a peacemaking nation if we concentrated on non-violent conflict resolution mechanisms and actually taught such skills to our diplomats and promoted that kind of resolution of conflict rather than arming ourselves to the teeth and being ready for this invasion which I do not believe is about to happen. Australia's contribution could be far more constructive if we were to develop a strategy of non-offensive or defensive defence for this country. This must be done outside the framework of a global strategy of the United States with its dangerously offensive and provocative strategies at sea such as the fleet exercises off the Siberian coast since 1982 and, of course, the predictable Soviet responses. The United States maritime strategy is very provocative and destabilising. We contribute to that by allowing Australia to be used as a listening post and information gathering post by that United States command.

What worries me about the emphasis on hardware and the whole militaristic approach to security is the chain reaction it starts off. India gets an aircraft carrier and nuclear submarines. Immediately there is talk here in Australia of acquiring nuclear submarines. Of course, there has always been hope for an aircraft carrier to replace HMAS Melbourne since it went to the scrapyard. I hope that the Government persists in refusing to bow to this pressure. I await the Oppositions's proposal on how it proposes to reconcile a cut in government expenditure with its suggestion to go for nuclear submarines, which I believe are totally unnecessary in the Australian situation. Of course, the Opposition is still considering aircraft carriers costing several billion dollars apiece.

What I am talking about here is the role of threat perceptions in today's strategic environment and the dangers of escalating a regional arms race which already involves a number of countries in South East Asia because of the situation there, especially in regard to Vietnam and Kampuchea. Our neighbours in South East Asia are arming themselves at an alarming rate. We do not need to buy into that model by trying to do the same. A lot of tension is created internationally by one country's perceptions of another country as a threat to it. We can reduce that threat perception by not arming ourselves to the teeth and by being seen as good neighbours and spending more money on foreign aid rather than on expensive and sophisticated weapons systems which actually suit the United States' purposes more than they suit us for the defence of Australia.

Australia has always had the problem of trying to flesh out a defence strategy when there is no threat to contend with-although, as a former air vice-marshall remarked not so long ago, if there were not a threat Australians would invent one. This continued emphasis on military hardware to cope with non-existent threats rather than using the almost unique security of our strategic environment to develop alternative models of conflict resolution is what concerns me most. We could spend, say, one per cent of our defence budget on conflict research to find better ways of resolving problems internationally rather than buying hardware. I am certainly concerned about reports that, having knocked off the Ambassador for Disarmament and our specialists on peace, disarmament and arms control in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, leaving that section of the Department grossly understaffed with the kind of expertise that is necessary, the hard men on the Right are now out to close the Peace Research Centre at the Australian National University (ANU). This is despite the important program it is developing this year on promoting security and arms control in the north Pacific and trying to hold back the escalating arms race at sea. It is most important that Australia contribute to this debate because at the moment we are, I believe, contributing to the destabilisation of the Pacific by our very close involvement with one of the major players in that arms race at sea. Therefore, the Peace Research Centre at the ANU has been doing a great deal of good work in promoting ways to find security in the region of the Pacific. This follows on from Bill Hayden's speeches in August and October last year. They were fine words but we really need some action to back them up.

I have also noticed the ridiculously inadequate budget set aside for the coastwatch program, which particularly affects Western Australia. Here there are day to day threats to Australia's security such as quarantine problems, illegal immigration and drug running. In one year we allocate only a fraction of the cost of one FA18 to that program. That is what we should be spending our defence dollars on. We really should be attending to the immediate security needs, to the reality of the situation, which is illegal immigration, drug running and quarantine problems. I believe that the Defence Department should be dealing with the Australian Customs Service and taking a great deal more action in regard to the protection of our western and northern coastlines, thus protecting our security from threats such as those. I have never really been able to understand why there has been the necessity for such a big argument about the coastwatch program. It seems to me that that is something that should be undertaken by the Department of Defence and not farmed out, at great expense to the taxpayer, to a private contractor.

I also want to comment on the $1.1 billion allocated for the transfer from Sydney of part of the fleet to Jervis Bay, a proposal which I consider to be quite ludicrous when no-one, particularly the Navy personnel and their spouses and families, wants to move from Sydney to Jervis Bay where there will not be jobs readily available for their families and, of course, where the social life cannot compare with that of Sydney. It seems that only a handful of bureaucrats in the Department of Defence want to make that move. If the Government is concerned about the loss of defence personnel, it might save the $1.1 billion, probably multiplied five or six times over in the next 20 years, by scrapping that unnecessary move to Jervis Bay.

One wonders what the reason is behind such a decision. I suspect that it has something to do, again, with our alliance with and subservience to the United States. Jervis Bay would be a very useful place for the United States naval fleet to call into. Of course, it would not be quite as accessible to people who are concerned about the entry of nuclear weapons and nuclear powered ships, which at the moment go to the more heavily populated centres such as Sydney. Jervis Bay would be well out of the way. It would be very convenient indeed for the United States navy to be able to use the very sophisticated facilities at Jervis Bay which Australia does not need at the moment. So that is another worrying aspect. By not moving to Jervis Bay the Defence Department could save itself some money and keep some of its personnel happy.

We have heard a lot in recent times about the wastage rates, the huge resignation rates, in the armed services. This is one thing that the Government could do to keep one section of the services happier than it is at the moment. There has been a lot of complaining about that proposed move.

I note that the Minister's statement refers to the recommendations of the Cooksey report. I cannot help but be aware of the contradiction of recommending a doubling of our defence exports with the speeches made by Australia in international fora on the subject of the global arms trade. Bill Hayden has made some very fine speeches on the subject of the global arms trade. He has said that Australia should not be flogging weapons to countries which are either at war, preparing for war or repressing their own peoples. That just about cuts out everybody that Australia is dealing with at the moment in terms of the arms trade. We should not get involved in that.

I think it is totally immoral for the Government to buy into the arguments that Cooksey has put forward about doubling Australia's exports in armaments to reduce our balance of trade deficit. Interestingly, I can agree with Senator MacGibbon who said about this report that it had never been made public or debated in this Parliament. Yes, I understand that recommendations that Cooksey made have been put in place by the Government. But, as I said, the report has never been discussed in this place. I think this is something which the Australian people ought to be aware of; they ought to have some input into that decision making process.

Of course, Australia is not one of the big players in the international arms bazaar. But by doubling our defence exports, we would be moving in that direction. We really need to think about whether this is the direction that we want Australia to move towards. Do we want to become involved in flogging weapons, the end result of which is to kill other human beings? I believe that this is an immoral and quite untenable position. It is not any answer for getting Australia out of its Budget crisis.

In the last few years there has been an alarming increase in new countries entering the global arms trade in order to help boost their domestic economy. The result can be seen in places like the Persian Gulf or some of the 25 bush wars referred to in an article in the Weekend Australian last Saturday. Again, we have to be aware of the ongoing effect of this-the whole process which is set in train with great competition between arms suppliers being prepared to sell their weapons indiscriminately and regardless of who is arguing or fighting against whom in any of the many conflicts which are raging in the world at the moment. This is not an area which I think Australia should be moving towards.

I have outlined on several occasions in this place proposals for a strategy of transarmament. I am sorry that the Government feels obliged to address itself today primarily to the thunder on the right rather than the constructive proposals for an alternative security and defence strategy given from the opposite perspective. I do, however, accept that until public opinion on this matter changes in Australia, it would be quite difficult for a government to put in place some of the more radical and yet sensible proposals which I have put forward. But I think the Government has an important job to do. It has to explain to Australians that we have a natural air-sea gap defence, that we are not about to be invaded and that we have natural defences. Even the people in the Defence Department are not talking about an invasion scenario at the moment. But this sort of thinking is fed by people in the extreme right wing lobby and it certainly needs to be countered.

We need to look towards the low level and medium level threats which ought to be resolved by talking out way out of trouble rather than by being prepared to fight our way out of trouble. Australia actually has no natural enemies. We are only on the Soviet Union's nuclear target list because of the presence of American bases on Australian soil. We ought to be able to get along with our neighbours in the Asian and Pacific region. I put forward most strongly the suggestion that we teach our diplomats conflict resolution mechanisms which involve talking our way out of trouble, rather than having to expend an enormous amount of money on weapons, most of which have nothing to do with the defence of Australia but which suit the United States.

If we can spend money on community education in respect of drugs and the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, I believe we can develop public thinking about security as well. I believe that security means freedom from fear. Of course, one of the fears we need to address is the invasion paranoia. But we also have to address the fears that people have about the things which our defence forces could make a genuine contribution towards, things like illegal immigration and drug running on our northern shores. So we have to consider what security really means. As I said, security means an absence from fear. We should not have as the highest priority the ridiculous fear of invasion which is not at all realistic.

If every country were to treat security purely in military terms and to build worst case scenarios as their rationale, and follow the recommendations of the Cooksey report by doubling their defence exports, the world would become an infinitely less secure place than it already is. I believe that Australia is in a very good position, with no natural enemies and as an island continent, to be a leader, as a peacemaker in the world. Of course, we have to start doing that by improving our relationships with our immediate neighbours and by discontinuing our grovelling subservience to the United States in terms of the nuclear alliance which we have with that country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing ourselves today to the defence policy statement made by Mr Beazley, I am reminded of a similar statement which was made by Mr Beazley only several weeks ago and which was tabled in this place. That statement looked at defence relationships in its region. I was very critical at that time of the way in which Mr Beazley approached regional defence and attitudes. What has changed in the progress report that has been tabled today, which follows the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities made 12 months ago? I think all that has happened is that Mr Beazley has changed his speech writer. Nothing else of any great import has come through. The statement that we have been given today is nothing but a shopping list-a list of supposed achievements; a list of reminders of things that still have to be done and have to take place. The statement is not particularly intellectual; it is not particularly detailed. It is really just a regurgitation. I believe that on this occasion the speech writer has probably been drawn from the Department of Defence itself rather than from someone else's private staff. My attention was recently drawn to a quote that was made by Sir Winston Churchill in 1904. Sir Winston said that the armed forces:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is not like a limited liability company, to be reconstructed from week to week as the money fluctuates. It is not an inanimate thing like a house, to be pulled down or enlarged or structurally altered at the caprice of the tenant or owner; it is a living thing. If it is bullied it sulks; if it is unhappy it pines; if it is harried it gets feverish; if it is sufficiently disturbed, it will wither and dwindle and almost die; and when it comes to this last serious condition, it is only revived by lots of time and lots of money.

The situation in which the Labor Government currently looks at the defence forces of Australia draws us to some very interesting comparisons with that quotation. Mr Beazley's statement today does nothing to give us any confidence or to give the members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) any confidence that they can rely on this Government to underpin and support their important function as part of our Australian lifestyle and community. The shopping list that we have here is, as I said a little earlier, only just a list of things that may still be done and a few things that we expect to be put out any time that Budget papers are looked at or incorporated. There is no mention in this paper of our relationship with the United States of America, the ANZUS Treaty or our alliance. It does not even feature, yet this is supposedly a major defence statement by Mr Beazley.

Senator Vallentine takes a very contrary view to the policies of both the Australian Labor Party and this Opposition. At least she has the courage to stand up here and put those views, which are very different from mine and from those of the Opposition, but Mr Beazley does not even acknowledge the area in which Senator Vallentine and many of her peace movement group hold very fundamental and strong views. Similarly, the views that I hold, which are very different from those of Senator Vallentine, are that we do need to have a very close relationship with the United States, we need to be able to put in place very strong Budget and defence compacts and treaties; we need to be able to work in a total partnership with America; and we ought not to share Senator Vallentine's paranoia in this area. The fact that Senator Vallentine speaks for only such a small percentage of the Australian electorate highlights the fact that a large number of people in Australia are looking to the Labor Party, the Government of Australia at this time, to come out with policies on which they can rely. Certainly, the Liberal and National parties have a very proud record both of past performance in this area and of present policies which look to the future.

Senator Vallentine also drew some comparisons about submarines. I think she said that we were looking at nuclear submarines because India was doing the same. What is wrong with looking to the Indian Ocean and to the defence changes and things that are happening in the Asian area and in India? India enjoys a very close relationship with the Soviet Union and, if there are important defence build-ups in India in which the Russians have their hand, we, in cooperation with America, should be looking to develop in those areas and to counter those build-ups. Beazley's statement makes no mention of this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tambling, it is customary to refer either to Mr Beazley or to the Minister for Defence, if you would be so kind.

—I shall certainly do so, Madam Acting Deputy President. The Minister makes no reference in his statement to what these proposals ought to be and to what our relationships should be in this area. The policy deals in some detail with developments for northern Australia. That interests me because my electorate is the Northern Territory. But if we compare the statements that are made in various parts of the paper we cannot find any real degree of consistency. In one part of Mr Beazley's statement he talks about the planning of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to move from Holsworthy to Darwin and the fact that it is well advanced. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Regiment should be installed in its new barracks by the end of 1992 . . . An examination of the implications of relocating a brigade to the north is also underway, with a study of the strategic, operational, logistic and personnel implications schedule for completion later this year.
That is, the examination is scheduled for completion later this year. Earlier in his statement the Minister said:

. . . the Government has decided to establish a northern command based at Darwin . . . It will be commanded by a brigadier supported by a staff drawn from the present 7th Military District Headquarters in Darwin together with Royal Australian Navy and Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) personnel.
He said further:
The new command should be operational by July this year.

I find a number of those statements basically inconsistent. As Senator MacGibbon said earlier in the debate, the Minister seems to have concentrated on one particular sector of the ADF -the Army. He has not looked at the necessary integration and come forward with the way in which this should be properly planned with the other forces. If we go further, it should also be very carefully planned and integrated with the civilian needs of northern Australia. What negotiations are under way with the Western Australian Government, with the Queensland Government, with the Northern Territory Government? If this type of a force is to be located in northern Australia, it needs very careful forward planning and a great deal of consultation. The Minister is not honest enough to give us any direction as to his thinking or as to what is happening in that regard. I am aware that certain discussions are taking place at various levels of the Defence Force in these areas, but obviously they have not yet flowed through for the Government to react to them or to set the conditions and the parameters in which the policies in this area ought to be developed.

Similarly, radical new policies need to be drawn up at this time with regard to coastal surveillance. The references in this statement do not draw us to any conclusions or to any firm basis on which coastal surveillance should be properly integrated with the defence forces. It certainly should be taken over by the defence forces. With the build-up of good bases across northern Australia that are planned and are to be put in place, it is a logical extension that coastal surveillance, with all of its civilian and military advantages, ought to be fully drawn in in that regard.

Okay, they are the sorts of policies that are being looked at, but what about the people who constitute the Australian defence forces, the men and women who make the Defence Force their career? What are they looking for and what can they expect from this statement. Other than the concluding paragraph, where the Minister acknowledges the dedication and professionalism of the men and women of the ADF, he makes no real substantive commitment to supporting the people who have made the defence force their life's work. I recently had a letter from a serviceman which looked at this issue. This serviceman was well aware that I sit on the defence subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, inquiring into wastages and why people are leaving the defence forces at the moment. This serviceman says:

Most employment groups of people tend to identify themselves, their circumstances and the peculiarities pertaining to their jobs as different. Servicemen are no different. However, there are a number of fundamentals which do make the lives and jobs of servicemen markedly different from most of their peers, within the community. In this respect the ADF is really no different from the experiences of Armed Forces in other countries . . . these fundamentals are seen to be:
High incidence of managerial imposed turbulence affecting families.
Imposition of a strict code of discipline.
Exposure, during some postings, to varying degrees of arduous working and living conditions.
Inability to effectively demonstrate dissatisfaction, other than by leaving the ADF.
Acquiring service-orientated qualifications (some attracting a compulsory Return of Service) which are broadly not transportable.
Constantly training and practising skills which are rarely (thankfully!) exercised in a real situation.

An oft voiced rejoinder to the above list is that people are aware of those factors when they join the ADF. There is some doubt in my mind that our recruiters are indeed that comprehensive in their discussions and at 16-18 years of age, it doesn't matter as much, as it does when you have a family and responsibilities.

We are dealing with thousands of Australians working in the Australian defence forces. These factors have to be properly recognised in the commitment that they give to the jobs they have chosen as a career for which they have been recruited after being solicited by the Australian Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of brief points. The basis of what I want to say is the identification of the threat or threats to which Australia is exposed because I think these have been wrongly identified hitherto. In the 1890s and the early part of this century the Western industrial world went through a period of enormous technical development. We developed a view of the world which said that if we faced a problem, that problem could be rendered into a technical problem and therefore we could find a technical solution to it. That thinking, certainly in the universities and in academic institutions, has been questioned and I think exploded since the end of the Second World War when we saw that there were really no defences to nuclear warfare. Unfortunately, in political life and in the area of defence that sort of thinking has continued. This paper provides a good example of that thinking and the problems it poses for us.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems are these: if one conceives political, social and economic problems in technical terms and seeks technical solutions to them, by and large one makes the problem worse. Certainly each technical solution to the problem of military defence has called forth greater technical innovation and defence on the part of supposed enemies which has rendered the problem more expensive to solve and more intractable. We are now spending something like $6m a minute worldwide in an attempt to guarantee security and in the past 40 years the world has become increasingly less and less secure. So, we should be seeking political and social solutions to what are essentially political and social problems.

I give a couple of examples to underline what I have been saying. Senator Vallentine pointed out that we have locked ourselves into an American alliance, a dependence on the American style of defence which is certainly based on a technical type of defence. I have in front of me an article from the journal Science of 27 November 1987, which points out that the American defence system to which we are wedded has come to depend heavily on the use of radar-very expensive radar systems. This article points out that the smart weapons that are being developed now are weapons that will track along radar beams so that the instant a ship, a tank or a plane sends out a radar signal it is identifying what it is, where it is, and a missile can simply fly along that radar beam and destroy it. The article begins by pointing out:

After serving for four decades as the primary shield against attack from the air, radar, is losing its defence power. With the advent of radar-seeking missiles and the military equivalent of the ``fuzzbuster''-
this term refers to the ability to detect radar speed traps on roads-
the combatant who relies heavily on radar will be in peril.

The sinking of the British destroyer HMS Sheffield with an Exocet missile during the Falkland War was a striking demonstration of how smart weapons have changed the rules of modern warfare. An Argentine fighter flying 20 miles away was able to destroy a $50-million warship with a single shot. Under slightly altered circumstances the target might have been one of two British aircraft carriers-a blow that could have reversed the outcome of the war.

The article goes on to point out that the large radar carried on the top of the line United States F15 fighter, for example, has a weight of 10,000 pounds, if its associated generators and air conditioners are added, or about one-fifth of the total weight of the plane, yet the Americans are going to spend an enormous amount of money on even more expensive radar. The article says:
. . . the Air Force and Navy are spending billions on radar jammers. For example, a $300-million program is under way to upgrade the jammers carried on 36 F-111 bombers . . .

It goes on further to point out that the airborne self-protection jammers are being developed at a cost of $5.5 billion. So our principal ally, the country that supplies the umbrella under which we are supposed to shelter, is finding that one of the key planks in its defence system not only has become no longer a defence but is aiding its vulnerability in the sense that anyone who uses radar in future wars is simply setting themselves up as a target.

The second example I would like to give is the example of electromagnetic pulse. Again, we have locked ourselves into the American defence system, which is based substantially on a nuclear defence. Most of the warships that visit Australia are nuclear powered and nuclear armed. The American defence literature states quite clearly that in the event of war the Americans would have to come quite quickly to depend upon nuclear weapons because that is the basis of their military strategy and technical hardware. It should be known in the Senate that one nuclear weapon, exploded at approximately 200 kilometres above the atmosphere, would destroy any radio or communication system which involved the use of transistors. This is because of the considerable electromagnetic pulse that passes through the atmosphere. This means that a war that became a nuclear war would rapidly escalate into total nuclear war, because one would lose the ability to fire retaliatory weapons. So, rather than lose them, one would use them. That would be the effect of that dependence upon a technical solution.

I return to the point made by Senator Vallentine that if in the area of defence we choose to rely more and more on technical solutions, we go down a road that makes us more vulnerable and less defensible. At the same time, that process soaks up large sums of money which could be better spent in creating conditions of peace rather than of war.

I should like now to pick up a point that Senator McLean made about the interlinking of civil defence with the idea of military defence. Many of the significant hazards faced by countries throughout the world involve the expenditure of large amounts of money on civil defence programs. For instance, every few years in Australia we have bushfires which cost this country hundreds of millions of dollars. Yet, to the extent that the military becomes involved, often it is brought in as a last resort. Moreover, the military is not specifically trained in the area of bushfire fighting. It would be extremely useful if the military were equipped for and had as one of its tasks the job of helping to defend this country against bushfires. In that connection Senator McLean mentioned the CL215 Canadian amphibious aircraft, about which both Senator McLean and I have made a submission in relation to northern surveillance.

Northern surveillance is another area in which we desperately need better civil defence. We need defence against fisheries incursions, drug runners, and problems of quarantining, particularly in the Torres Strait region. We need to have the ability to move people in quickly to intercept those who are breaking the law or imposing a threat to this country. Those matters are simply not being addressed at the present time. That is a task for the military, which could be well tackled by the purchase and use of this amphibious aircraft, which can transport fully equipped landing parties; and that aircraft can be used also in fighting bushfires. It can scoop up six tonnes of water in 10 seconds and repeatedly fly low over a bushfire and drop that water, with or without retardant.

The notion that comes through this paper that military and civil defence are separate is one that I think needs to be seriously questioned. Great benefit would flow to Australia if our defence forces were to participate principally in a civil defence role, and hopefully never had to be used in a military role. I believe, like Senator McLean, that that would not only increase the morale of the defence forces because they would be involved in activities which were seen by the community to be useful, but also improve the economics of the military operation because those activities would be useful. Exercises should be more than merely military exercises, and perhaps never to be used activities. From the point of view of the acceptance by the community of military forces, the community would have a much better attitude towards them because of their extreme usefulness.

I return to the primary point which I wish to emphasise. That is that there are problems which by their very nature are not technical. The attempt to render them as technical, and to seek technical solutions to them, usually compounds the problems, and makes them more intractable. It does not help to advance the solution. I believe that is what has happened particularly since the Second World War in the area of military preparedness. There is a misconception about the nature of that problem. The attempt to find technical solutions has made the solutions more expensive, and has not guaranteed safety. On the contrary, it has guaranteed greater vulnerability.

Finally I would like to acknowledge the dedication and professionalism of the men and women of the ADF who are responding to the challenges of the White Paper to build the Defence Force we need to make self-reliance a reality, and guarantee Australia's security into the next century.

I suppose we must be pleased that at last the Minister has realised that he has men and women in the Defence Force. If he takes a deep breath or shuts his eyes, there may be none left when he finishes breathing or opens his eyes. The situation is becoming desperately serious. It is not as if he has not been warned over many months in this place. At last he mentions the men and women in the Defence Force. Somebody has told him that he has to make a statement. I have been telling him for some time that he has to make a statement. I did not expect it to be by way of the last paragraph of a 27-page statement. I suppose it is a start. He is a bit of a slow learner. Nevertheless, the statement shows that this Government is not coming to grips with the entrenched problem it faces with the Australian defence forces. I do not intend today to go into all the detail of actions which I believe the Government could take to deal with the problem because I am making a very detailed submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am very glad to think that the Parliament was so concerned and incensed about this problem that, when the Government would not take action, the Committee forced the Government to face the problem through having an inquiry. Hopefully, that will bring the reality of the situation home to the people of this country-those who have not yet realised what is happening-and also, very seriously to the Government. The Government, urgently, has to do something meaningful to reverse the situation.

I wish to flick through a few pages because the statement contains some things on which I wish to comment. On page 2 the Minister says that he wants to report the progress he has made over the past year in making self-reliance a reality for Australia. I do not know what he intends to do. Does he intend to park all our mothballed equipment across, perhaps, the Tropic of Capricorn and see whether that will keep the invading hordes out and keep us self-reliant? I do not think that he has enough people to man it. He certainly cannot get his planes in the air. His only strike squadron in Darwin has something like 18 planes and seven pilots. I think that it is a load of rubbish to talk about making any progress at all towards self-reliance in the last year. He has been going backwards. He talked about the new clarity which the White Paper has brought to defence planning. It might have brought clarity, but it has not brought any action. He said that it is fundamental to the Government's defence policy that our defence posture must be affordable. Of course that is so, but honourable senators will recall that we had a great deal of palaver about what proportion of gross domestic product he would spend each year and what sort of real growth he would have in his defence budget each year. He has gone slowly backwards. I think that this year he is going backwards even faster. God knows what will happen in the May mini-Budget. The Minister is very ready to talk about this sort of thing having happened before in 1976, but he does not have the guts to acknowledge that the same thing has just happened to him.

As I have said, the Minister gave a huge emphasis to his capital investment program and claimed that he has kept the White Paper on track. How can he expect us to believe that when, quite clearly, equipment purchases are being slipped, despite the fact that he will not acknowledge it; ceilings are being cut in manpower in order to be able to afford to keep going, and he is wasting parts of the defence budget by the grossly inflated training costs that the nation is having to face in order to replace the men and women we are losing? I have spoken at length on that many times in this chamber and I do not intend to go on about it again today. But it is on the record that costs from losing these people and having to recruit, select and train new people are enormous. What we have left is still an inexperienced Defence Force. So we are in no way able to replace what we are losing. The Minister is not prepared to come to grips with that in his 27-page statement.

The Minister said that Norcom would be operational by July this year. That has been in the pipeline for a long time. He talked at some length about Kangaroo 89-a major Defence Force exercise which will take place in the north next year. I was interested to see that the Minister said that it will exercise the Defence Force's ability to respond to widely dispersed low level threats. If ever a statement could attract a sad, hollow laugh, that is it. Quite clearly, what we will see from that exercise-if that is what the Defence Force is to do-is our inability to respond to widely dispersed low level threats happening at the same time. That is the enormity of what the Minister is presiding over. The Minister said also in the statement:

Our forces must have a comprehensive range of defensive capabilities-including air defence, mine counter-measures, and protection of coastal trade-and must embody mobile land forces able to defeat hostile incursions at remote locations.

Sadly, the Government rejected Project Waler. It has not come to grips with the decision about the M113. We do not have the ability to get our land forces over the sort of terrain with which we have to cope in northern Australia. The Government will not make a decision on the matter. It has been in the pipeline for far too long.

The Minister said also that his Defence Force needs to be deployable and effective in the most likely areas of operation. We recognise that that is very much likely to be northern Australia, but we have a difficult coastline. We have to be able to get our forces across the shore or resupply them across the shore. We have little or no amphibious capacity in this country. We have heavy landing craft laid up in Cairns because the Navy does not have the manpower to bring them out of mothballs. If our forces are to be effective in the most likely areas of operation, we have to improve our intelligence gathering capability. It takes us days to discover that we have trochus gatherers off Broome and up our creeks. It takes so long that by the time we get anybody there to intercept them, we have lost some. We do not know exactly what they were doing. We believe that they were only gathering trochus.

We have had a number of debates in this place about coastal surveillance and the contract for that. We have heard Major-General Grey, the recently retired head of the Australian Federal Police, talking about the inadequacies of our northern surveillance. We certainly need to have the command and control of that northern surveillance put into the hands of the Defence Force with a special, clearly defined vote for the purpose. There is no reason why the Department cannot employ civilian contractors to do part of the work. This is an area that in wartime would be required to be covered by the Defence Department and it is quite nonsensical for that Department not to be getting the peacetime experience of coordinating the very many ships and planes that are needed to do the job for the various departments.

We are really totally inadequately protected from the north. I think that it is in today's Australian that Air Marshal Evans is reported as being pretty trenchant about the lack of surveillance of our northern approaches. I know that in November last year in the Australian Air Commodore Tex Watson was reported to have said that 80 per cent of our high level airspace and 99 per cent of our low level airspace in the north was not watched at all. That is just a desperately worrying thing. Recently when I was in the Northern Territory I found that the question of defence was uppermost in people's minds. They understand just how vulnerable this country is. We sit down here in this part of Australia and perhaps do not take defence as seriously as we ought. Those people realise that Cam Ranh Bay is closer to them than are the three guided missile destroyers in Sydney Harbour. There are 40 Soviet guided missile destroyers in Cam Ranh Bay and these are closer to Darwin than the three in Sydney Harbour.

We have only an air traffic control radar and an air defence radar in Darwin. They cannot see over the horizon because they have a range of about 30 kilometres only. Shortly we will have an air traffic control radar at Tindal but that will hardly extend our watching capacity at all. It takes four days to get a patrol boat to steam from Perth to the north-west corner of Australia. We have a total inability to keep a watch on and to patrol around our northern coast. We have to do something urgently about it.

The Minister for Defence talked about a network of operational over the horizon radars. He talked about the vast sea and air gap. I recognise that in fact action has been taken in this area to try to achieve something-but not enough. I believe it is a matter of the highest priority. In my book, it is more urgent than some of the equipment on order, which is much more expensive. I think that in priority terms I would have to put our intelligence gathering capacity, along with the maintenance of an experienced manpower in the Services at the very top of the list. I could not find any reference in the Minister's statement to airborne early-warning and control aircraft-once again, something which the Government has been delaying making a decision on.

The Minister referred to the basing of half the fleet in Western Australia. He trots that out every time he makes a defence statement. However, I am acutely aware of the fact that we cannot put half our fleet in Western Australia because at this stage the DDGs and the FFGs are not able to be lifted by the ship lift which is being installed in Western Australia. I acknowledge that in a year or so that ship lift will have an expanded capacity to take the larger ships. From reading the Minister's statements on this matter, one would not realise that in fact Western Australia is not presently capable of handling half the fleet. There are other inadequacies that have not been addressed in planning to put half the fleet in Western Australia, but I do not intend to go into detail of that now.

It takes quite a time just to turn the pages of the Minister's statement because it is pretty thick. As I mentioned earlier, so much of it is a repeat of previous material issued by the Minister. However, on page 21 of the statement, in relation to defence personnel, the Minister says:

This Government has given unprecedented attention to this issue. My colleague Mrs Kelly has been appointed to undertake a thorough overhaul of Defence personnel issues and her work in this area is both very important and very complex. Anyone who believes that the solutions in this area are simple does not understand the problem.
We have allocated substantial funds to rectify deficiencies in the personnel area which have been building up over many years.

I recognise that the problems of manpower are not new, but never have we seen them in the catastrophic proportions that we are now facing. I draw attention to the fact that some of these manpower problems are directly Government-instigated, partly because of the break-up in the defence budget whereby far too high a proportion of the budget has not gone into equipment purchases and far too small a percentage is now in manpower. Only 42 per cent of the defence budget now relates to personnel. That should be at least 50 per cent if the Government is to do anything meaningful in that area. Secondly, the Government just in the last year has introduced ceilings on Defence Force manning levels which have dramatically reduced its capacity to do the job that the Government requires it to do. Therefore, in a very real sense the Government is making the problems.

I do not believe that the Government really is grasping the nettle in doing something meaningful about it. Anyone who has followed the progress of this matter over the last few years would realise that the Government is actually going to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal time after time and arguing against increases in wages for the defence forces. The defence force personnel do not have a union. They do not have the right to strike. When the government of the day, their employer, takes advantage of them in that way, by going to the Tribunal set up with such a flourish to try to improve the arrangements for paying them, it is clear why the morale of the defence forces has plummeted as it has. The Government has in its own hands several ways to immediately improve the morale of the forces-for example, in regard to Defence Force ceilings and not fighting the forces when it comes to claims in regard to pay and conditions before the Tribunal.

One thing that concerns me is that the Government has just recently taken the Remuneration Tribunal out of the Defence Department and placed it in the Department of Industrial Relations. That was supposed to show that the Department of Defence was not fighting itself and thereby disheartening service men and women who felt that their own leaders were arguing against their case. All that has happened is that we have little secret visits by senior officers of the Department of Defence to the Department of Industrial Relations for consultations with officers of that Department who will conduct the case for the Commonwealth against the defence forces in the Tribunal. Therefore, all that has happened is that the Government has sent it underground in a very deceitful manner. I cannot imagine Bill Kelty being too happy if the Government were to deal with trade union claims before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in that way. It seems to be okay to do that to service men and women because they are not unionists and, therefore, presumably, are not mates. This Government seems to care only about its mates.

I cannot accept the Minister's statement that the Government is giving unprecedented attention to the issue, that it is doing anything meaningful or that the solutions are not simple. The Minister said that anyone who believes that the solutions in this area are simple does not understand the problem. Of course, it is a very complex matter, but there are several ways in which the Minister himself could by decree tomorrow improve things quite meaningfully. For instance, had he reversed the proportion of his statement going to equipment vis-a-vis personnel-had he had a page devoted to equipment and 20 pages to personnel-we might have been able to start to believe that he really was committed to doing something for service men and women.

Once more the Minister is just putting out his same old list of toys that he is so very proud of. But there is a lot which he should not be proud of. There is a lot for which he should be condemned. The Minister has presided over the diminution of capability and experience in the Australian Defence Force which will stand as a lasting condemnation of his handling of the defence portfolio. Increasingly, the Australian people are starting to realise just what this Minister for Defence and this Government have presided over. Our ability to defend ourselves and all of the talk about self-reliance will be for nothing if we cannot keep the professional and highly trained men and women in the Defence Force.

The Minister's progress report is just more of the same. We should give him a good shake to make him realise the seriousness of what he has presided over. But I fear that he is unteachable. He has been long enough in his job to know that he has been going down the wrong track. He was interested in the question of defence long before he got the defence portfolio. If anyone should have seen the dangers in the action that he has been taking, it should have been this Minister. That is why I am all the more disappointed that someone with such a background in this area should have let the defence forces down so badly. They had extremely high hopes of this man.

We all know that the Australian media was touting the Minister as the best Defence Minister that this country has ever seen. Sadly, he has forfeited all that. He has not been strong enough in Cabinet to keep the Defence budget at the level at which it should have been kept. There has been an inability or unwillingness on his part to see that the amount spent on personnel did not go down to a point where it would damage the Defence Force and its capability. He has not carried out his responsibilities properly and the country is the worse off for it. God help that we do not suffer from some unforeseen happening. We have to remember that we live in a very uncertain world and in a very unstable part of the world. We cannot trade on the fact that nothing will happen to us. We cannot afford to lose the experience and expertise that we have. Therefore, I am astonished, disappointed and quite disillusioned that these 27 pages of repetition could still come from a Minister who should know better.

Apart from the world conservation area in far north Queensland there are very many areas where we can see, on reading the report, that quite a lot of work is being done to preserve our heritage.
