As I read through the report I was very interested to see the national estate grants program this year and quite a large list of projects in Queensland. Sometimes, when we listen to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and other people speaking, we would think that nobody had preserved anything in Queensland. But there most certainly are lots of very worthwhile projects there. This is really very important. Our mall in Brisbane has just been extended. One important part was the facading that was done. Page 28 of the report talks about facadism. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: `Facadism' is a term used to describe the practice of retaining the facade of an old building while demolishing the rest of it to make way for modern development.

The report says that there has been a deal of debate on whether this is a good idea for preserving buildings. The modern Myer store is there and the facades of quite a number of old buildings have been retained. I hope that in future years, as young people grow up and look at these buildings, they will realise what the buildings looked like earlier.

There are many other areas involved in keeping our heritage. We also read on page 37 about the historic environment many years ago in the Palmer goldfield in far north Queensland. It is even further north than our rainforest area that we talk about so much these days in the Senate. The Palmer area is the area where the Chinese came to, many years ago to find gold. This goldfield contains mines, settlements, roads and Chinese workings dating from the 1870s onwards. On one or two occasions when I have been in Cooktown I have found a Chinese proverb in the museum there. I am sure Senator Puplick would be very interested in the proverb, which went like this:
To be happy for a day, take a wife. To be happy for a week, kill a pig. To be happy all your life, plant a garden.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very big on gardens.

—I thought Senator Puplick would be. I thought I would read that into the Hansard this afternoon. Many areas in Brisbane, indeed in Queensland, are important for our heritage. In Kingaroy on 9 April we are going to open a heritage museum. Signs of what has been done in the area over the past years will be kept for the future. There will be machinery and a history of the peanut industry, how it started in the early days and how it has grown. Looking around Brisbane, there is Newstead House, the home of Queensland's first Governor and there are three houses in the Expo site area which people are very anxious to protect and preserve after Expo has gone.
—There were a few hotels they wanted to conserve too but they got knocked down. Do you remember?

—There have been other areas. When one looks around Brisbane and sees the tremendous growth and development taking place, one has to admit that some of the buildings had to go. If the honourable senator is thinking of the Bellevue Hotel, that hotel was falling to pieces anyway. The verandas were falling down. That is the whole story about that building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, in particular for the wisdom of the Chinese proverb. I will spare her the one I know, which is an Arab proverb dealing with women, boys and sheep. I might enlighten her on that at some later stage. There are one or two matters arising from the Australian Heritage Commission annual report which need to be brought to the Senate's attention. The first is that when I was reading the section on page 40, I was staggered to see a figure given that there had been 1,368 removals from the register of interim list or rejected nominations. It was only when I found the errata document floating around in the report that I realised that figure is not 1,368 but only 368. I think there should be some responsibility on organisations to ensure that the proofreading of their reports is sufficiently up to scratch that the little errata slips that get put into annual reports, which most people manage to lose at some stage, do not confuse the whole position.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad that Senator Richardson is in the chamber because I want to draw attention to the fact that this report is signed by Mr Pat Galvin, the Acting Chairman of the Commission. Mr Galvin made a speech to the Fourth World Wilderness Congress held in Colorado in September last year, which was recently reprinted in the Australian Heritage Commission's newsletter of December 1987. One of the things Mr Galvin said is:

In Australia we have not found it easy to put into practice the principle of conserving living natural resources for sustainable development. In our experience this has and will continue to be a difficult and challenging assignment.
I fail to be convinced that development and conservation are natural bedfellows.

That is a point of view which I reject. It is a point of view which fundamentally the national conservation strategy for Australia rejects. It is therefore very important, given all the qualifications which Mr Galvin subsequently makes in the article, that we understand that this presumably is to become the underlying philosophy of the Heritage Commission in this matter. Mr Galvin goes on to say:
They can be brought together in appropriate circumstances with deliberate effort . . .

Nobody disagrees with that. But the idea that development and conservation are not natural bedfellows seems to me to be quite wrong. It may be that preservation and development are what Mr Galvin has in mind, because there is a difference between preservation and conservation. I think there needs to be some greater clarity. If that is what the Acting Chairman means, that is what he should say in his public statements.

Two other matters arise from the report. The first is that when one looks at the increasing pace of nominations, which is referred to on page 11 of the report, many of the arguments which were canvassed in the debate on the Australian Heritage Commission (Notification of Owners) Amendment Bill, introduced by Senator Walters the other day, are given some additional force in terms of the rights of people to be consulted in these matters. The second is that when one looks at the section headed `Tax incentives for heritage conservation' one's attention must be once again drawn to the quite contradictory policies that the Government has pursued in relation to the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on heritage properties and on the payments made to conservators, curators and resident caretakers as far as national trust and heritage properties are concerned.

I see from the smile on Senator Richardson's face that he undoubtedly believes in pectore that he will be able to solve this matter in the mini-Budget or the next round of Budget negotiations. I wish him the best of luck in that respect with Mr Keating and Senator Walsh. Nevertheless, assurances have been given to people that the Government has this matter under consideration. But those assurances have been given now for a prolonged time and there has really been no satisfactory resolution of what has been an outstanding and significant problem for the Heritage Commission in the protection of heritage properties. I hope that in the next couple of months that matter will be resolved in a more satisfactory fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the Australian Heritage Commission annual report 1986-87. The Australian Democrats are committed to attempting to establish a sustainable economy and ecology and, therefore, it is essential to know what we have, where it is, how much of it there is and by whom it is owned. Associated with this is our attempt to establish a register of foreign ownership, as nobody quite knows who owns Australia, so that if we can buy back the farm, if we have the political will to do this, we will at least know how we can start to set about it. The Australian Heritage Commission is concerned with identifying places of National Estate significance and compiling a Register of the National Estate and, to quote page 3:

SPEECH.PARA: To further public interest in and understanding of the National Estate . . .

The National Estate registers places which are regarded as significant. It is worth looking at the Commission's objectives for this Register. I seek leave to incorporate those objectives on page 78 of the report in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The objectives read as follows-
The Commission's objectives for the Register are for it to:
be a comprehensive list of places in Australia which have significance heritage value;
alert Australians to the presence of places of heritage significance;
give all decision makers, non-government and government, objective information about places of heritage significance to help them make better informed decisions;
educate Australians about the natural and cultural history of their country;
ensure that due consideration is given to the national estate values of listed places before Commonwealth decisions and actions are taken; and
provide a focus and direction for the National Estate Grants Program and Australian Heritage Grants Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —These objectives apply to a number of different aspects of our heritage-that is, our natural environment, built or historic environment, the Aboriginal environment and our history. There are areas of conflict, and I refer to page 16 of the report under the heading of `The woodchipping question'. The areas dealt with here in some detail are Tasmania, Eden-Monaro-where the new New South Wales Government has said that logging will start immediately-and the Denmark area in south-west Western Australia. Although the McLean's woodchip proposal has been rejected by the Western Australian State Government, page 18 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: While some of the places listed in or nominated for the Register are designated as future national parks in the strategy, others are designated as State forests and, under current proposals, will be subject to intensive forest management by WACAP-
Western Australia Chip and Pulp-
an operation which will largely destroy their national estate value.

A familiar tactic in the battle to preserve areas of beauty and significance from so-called development is to destroy that beauty as quickly as possible so as to take away any chance of its recognition as potential National Estate. Of course, that is one of the reasons why the conservation legislation is currently before the Senate.

Whilst Fremantle in Western Australia is a partial success and has survived the razzamatazz of the boat race virtually unscathed-there is mention of this on page 35-the city of Perth has been turned into a nightmare of lost heritage. We now have a pathetic facade of the Palace Hotel paddling at the foot of Alan Bond's 48-storey phallic symbol. However, there is some good news-the 1910 Perth Technical College building in St George's Terrace has just been put on the interim list of heritage listing, so the Castle Keepers and others who have fought for some three years to save that building can take some hope. In fact, it is very sad to read of the losses from the National Estate during the 1986-87 year. In Western Australia these include the Cheriton Arch in Gingin, part of the Trigg-Karrinyup Reserve in Stirling and the former Sons of Gwalia mine headframe and winder, Gwalia. I commend this report and urge the Government to take note of the Commission's hopes and fears for the future.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Senator Cook:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now turns to the debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988. At the beginning I draw attention to the name and intention of the Bill-to create a statutory authority called the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority; it does not introduce the Government's plan for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. The Opposition does not oppose the Government's plan for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. We support the broad thrust of the restructuring proposed. We believe that the plan moves in the right direction as it gradually reduces barrier protection to the industries and eliminates the quantitative restrictions while encouraging firms to be more competitive internationally. The plan has been accepted by the industries and their council and it has been accepted by the union movement; we wish it well. There are some modifications which we would have made to it had we been in government, but we support it and when we get into government we will continue with it. I say that so that industries can understand that they can make decisions confident in the knowledge that after the next election, when the Liberal and National parties are in government, their plan will continue.

SPEECH.PARA: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Bill

When I first saw this Bill and examined the nature of the proposal which the Government had put before the Parliament I was quite horrified. The Bill is inquisitive, intrusive and contains such draconian powers that I could not support it in the form presented by the Government. I therefore determined to recommend to my colleagues that the Bill be opposed because of the draconian powers. Although I have a limited time for this speech I may get time to go into this matter later. I draw attention to the fact that the Law Council of Australia has written to me and others, urging the Senate to refrain from passing the Bill in its present form and to provide an opportunity for the Law Council's concerns to be appropriately considered. Those attacks by the Law Council and Mr Garry Downes, QC, the Chairman of the Council's Administrative Law Committee, could probably be considered by the Senate. Similar attacks are contained in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I will deal with that very quickly by saying that as a result of the representations I have made to Senator Button the Government has agreed to introduce a large number of amendments which in many ways deal with the draconian powers, although in my view not fully enough. However, they will be a matter for debate in committee.

Senator Cook, on behalf of Senator Button, tabled a speech in the Senate in which he circulated the Government's amendments. He said that the purpose of the amendments was to clarify the meaning of some clauses where there may be some confusion or concern and to reduce the formality in the conduct of inquiries by the authorities. That paragraph, those sentences, are a euphemism for Senator Button acknowledging that it is the Government's intention to gut the draconian powers from the Bill. As I say, it does not go far enough and if we reach that stage I shall be moving further amendments.

I might say also that the first time there was any mention of this plan back in November 1986, the then Opposition shadow Minister, Senator Chaney, indicated that there was concern on our side with the creation of a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. I refer to his Press release of 28 November 1986 when he said:
Important questions remain unanswered about a number of things including the role, size and cost of the TCF development authority.

Having this view about this draconian measure-I would recommend to my colleagues that they oppose it because of its draconian powers-we went further and looked at the whole purpose of the Bill. We could see immediately that the establishment of the development authority was not necessary for the Government's plan. I shall now devote some attention to explaining my reasons for saying that it is not necessary, therefore there is no need to have this authority. For that reason the Opposition parties will be opposing the second reading of the Bill. As I said, right from the word go, Senator Chaney, on behalf of the Opposition parties, indicated some concern about the creation of another statutory authority. I have to say that the Government and some people in the industries seem to have mixed up restructuring and structures. Some people seem to think that an authority will solve the problem of these industries. I draw the attention of those people to the parallel example of the Steel Industry Authority, from which there have been warnings that have been ignored in the past. I draw attention to the fact that the Steel Industry Authority has not resolved the problems of the steel industry in Australia. I say to the TCF industries that they ought to be very wary about this particular authority. Quite frankly, in the Opposition's view, more bureaucratic controls are not the answer.

The industries consider it is important to have a single body monitoring the impact of the TCF plan, but we say to the industries a new statutory authority is simply not the answer. The creation of another body would result in four separate bodies providing advice to the Minister and the Government on TCF industries matters and various aspects of the TCF plan. These bodies would be the TCF section of the Department, the TCF Industry Council, the Australian Customs Service and the proposed new statutory authority. I shall come back to those later.

The coalition believes firmly that the interests of the industries and the Australian community in general will not be advanced by the establishment of this Authority. It is not necessary to create a quango to implement the plan. This quango would be burdensome and expensive. The Bill's explanatory memorandum only gives the costings for the remainder of the financial year 1987-88. It gives those costings as $1.2m for the part year. This Authority is to operate until 1996. I point out to the industries that this authority could be the vehicle for substantive changes to the plan as they understand it. The safeguard mechanism the industries are so concerned about is not detailed in the Bill. I might add that I do not think it will ever be used because Senator Cook has already warned the industries that there could be changes to the plan. I draw attention to the second reading speech of the Minister, in which he said:
I should say however that the industries cannot expect the plan to be immutable and that industry planning should take into account other factors such as macro-economic circumstances.
If ever I have heard a warning to industries that when the Government introduces its across the board tariff cut in May it will suffer an across the board tariff cut, it is in that paragraph:
The industries cannot expect the plan to be immutable . . .
As if that is not bad enough, he actually spells it out when he says:
. . . industry planning should take into account other factors such as macro-economic circumstances.
I draw attention to the fact that the industries wanted a monitoring authority. As Senator Cook says in his second reading speech:

The establishment of such a body was recommended by the TCF Industry Council in its consideration of . . . assistance . . . The council saw the need for a specialised monitoring authority with responsibility for identifying the nature of changes occurring under the plan and with the provision for advisory powers to remedy any deficiencies in the plan's operations.
So, that is what the industries wanted. Senator Cook went on to say:
I see the role of the Authority as being broader than that envisaged by the Council.
He then went on to say that the main function of the body will be to administer the industries' development strategy but he had already said in his second reading speech:
The main function of the Authority will be to implement the industries' development strategy.

So, its main function will be to implement and administer the industries' development strategy. Where in this Bill is the discussion about the monitoring role? Only in one clause, where the Bill provides that when the Authority conducts its review, which is to occur not later than 30 June 1992, it may then recommend in its report, if it considers that the industries have contracted too much, that the operations of the policies be suspended for such period not exceeding one year as specified in the report or, if it considers it is necessary to revise the policy, that the Commonwealth call for an inquiry to be conducted for the purpose of examining and recommending changes to those policies. The protective mechanism is as weak as water. All the Authority can do is recommend to the Government deferral for up to one year of the plan. The Government will not have to accept that recommendation, if the Authority ever gets around to making such a recommendation. If the Authority thinks that the industries have contracted too much and there is great concern about the contraction, all that it will do is recommend to the Government that the Government conduct an inquiry. However, the Authority has been conducting an inquiry right from the moment of its commencement. The Authority will have draconian powers, which the Minister will not totally do away with, and may, as provided in proposed section 7 (m), prepare and maintain a database on the TCF industries, and, as provided in proposed section 7 (n), conduct such inquiries as it considers necessary for the proper performance of its functions.

So, the Authority will keep a database on the industries, it will monitor them, and it will conduct any inquiries that it considers necessary for its purposes. However, when it comes to seeing that the industries are in real trouble, instead of being able to tell the Government to do something, all that the Authority will be able to do under those proposed subsections is to suggest to the Government that it inquire into its policies and consider whether some changes should be made. I advise the industries that there is no industry safeguard mechanism within this Bill. The industries will be totally reliant on what Senator Button has said in his various speeches, and on his honouring the promises he made in those speeches. There is nothing in this legislation which will really give assistance to the industries if Senator Button decides that he will allow the industries to contract to a greater extent than they expect. The industries wanted someone to keep an eye on the plan. However, the Government will only establish a massive quango to implement the plan, and organise and restructure the industries, with powers of investigation which are quite substantial even despite their having been gutted by the Government.

I add also that the Authority will be an administering an industry development strategy body which will dispense less than $100m over a period of eight years. So, it will provide about $12m a year in financial assistance to the industries. I point out that there are sections in the Minister's Department, supported by external boards, not statutory authorities, which administer grants and funding assistance packages of a similar magnitude to, or even greater than, $12m. I refer to the Industries Research and Development Incentives Board, the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board and the Shipbuilding Consultative Group.

A simple industry advisory committee-the sort of body the Opposition believes could have been established-could provide the consultation and monitoring mechanisms envisaged by the Industry Council. Alternatively, that council could perform those functions as part of its normal activities. The Industry Council, with the assistance of the Department, would have been able to do all that was required.

I mentioned the duplication of functions, including the overlapping of functions of the Australian Customs Service, the Department and the Industry Council. I draw attention to departmental officers. They should administer the grant of financial assistance, particularly as other external bodies, for example, the Australia Industry Development Corporation, are checking the viability of business plans as part of the sectoral plan. Further, departmental staff will continue to monitor overseas developments. However, the desire for the establishment of the Authority is a statement of the lack of confidence which the Government has in the Department's ability to monitor developments in Australia.

The Opposition parties say that the implementation and monitoring of the plan can be adequately done by the Department. We give a commitment that when we are in government this will occur. However, the Opposition parties are in the business of reducing government expenditure and not increasing it. A statutory authority is simply not necessary for the successful implementation of the plan. The Government refers to other sectoral plans as justification for a statutory authority for the TCF industries. However, experience in those industries confirms our view that a statutory authority is not necessary or appropriate.

The steel industry and other authorities have not hastened results in their industries. In fact, last week there was a very timely example of why the community and the industries do not need an authority, and why the existence of such a body will not be in the best interests of everyone. I refer to the response by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) in the other place with regard to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the Australian iron and steel industry. I should preface my remarks by saying that the House of Representatives Committee made recommendations that all sorts of things should happen, take place or be done in relation to this plan. The Minister said:
Members may be aware that the Steel Industry Authority is presently conducting a review of the Steel Industry Plan.
He said further:
It would not be appropriate therefore to respond at this stage to the specific findings and recommendations of the Parliamentary Committee's report.

That is exactly the sort of thing that concerns me about this industry. The stage will be reached where clearly something has to be done desperately. However, instead of the Government being required or pushed into taking some action the Minister will say that the Government cannot do anything because the Authority is currently examining the matter, and the Government will have to await its report. That has been happening with the steel industry over a period of about two years or a little more with regard to the disasters that have been occurring at Port Kembla. The Minister has been putting that off by saying that the steel industry is doing this, or looking at that. Now, when the industry has had a three-month period during which things have begun to go right at Port Kembla, the Government says that the Steel Industry Authority is about to report on this matter. Really! Governments will use quangos to avoid doing things which are difficult for a government to do, but which have to be done. I believe that Mr Jones's response to the House of Representatives Committee report was quite cavalier. It indicates the Government's intention to manipulate the Authority to enable discussions to replace decisions, and to distance itself from responsibility.

The Government intends that the Authority will have a broad involvement in determining what are responsible labour management plans and in allocating financial assistance based on its decisions. To me it seems that the Government intends to stick its nose into matters. One would have to be very worried about that because it will intrude into management's plans. Further, of course, the Authority will determine who receives what grants. That is really intrusive. I warn those companies which are concerned about their future that they will find this Authority not to be of real value to them. Proposed section 10 (4) gives the Authority the power to report on any instance that it considers is one of failure by a person involved in any of the TCF industries to act consistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government with respect to those industries. That is an extraordinarily intrusive power. This Authority will be able to report any person who has failed to act consistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government with regard to those industries. If, for example, the Commonwealth Government has a policy of equal employment, any person not acting in accordance with that policy may be reported by the Authority to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I referred to clause 10 of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill but, in view of the limited time left to me, I will return to that clause during the committee stage of the debate. The Opposition parties have a great concern for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. We recognise the great contribution which those industries have made in the past and continue to make to Australian industry. Indeed, before I became a member of the Senate, I was a director, and ultimately chairman of directors, of a textile company. I recognise the contribution which that company made to the industry and to the country town in which it operated. The contribution which those industries make not only to Australia in general but to rural towns especially is very significant. Our concern ought to be contrasted with the supposed concern of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The second reading speech, which was made by Senator Cook on behalf of Senator Button, said at page 5 that this plan is about restoring dynamism to industries which have lost their competitive edge. Quite frankly, that is not true. There have been massive investments in these industries in recent years. I quote from page 2 of the Minister's second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The TCF industries have grown up behind significant import barriers and as a consequence have been insulated from the realities of operating in the international environment.

I say to the Minister that many TCF companies in Australia are at the leading edge of technology in the world. They are as efficient as any TCF industry in the world. Massive investments have been made in those industries in recent years. Their problem is the whole structure of industry in Australia-wages, hours of work, oncosts and government costs. That is their problem; it is not that they are inefficient. On the contrary, as I have said, they are technically efficient. They may be economically inefficient in some aspects in the international world market, but that is not their fault. The conditions under which those companies are required to operate are this Government's fault-Australia's fault. We are desperately concerned about these industries. We recognise that, as a consequence of this plan, some companies will go to the wall.

If we really believed that this plan could not be implemented without a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, we would have approved of the Development Authority. The simple truth is that this plan can be implemented without this Authority; the Authority is not necessary. The Authority is a bureaucratic, inquisitive, intrusive and dictatorial organisation which is totally unnecessary. In out view, it will be just another massive bureaucracy and will create problems for companies. There are many reasons, which I have already outlined, why we are totally opposed to the Authority, but fundamentally it is for the benefit of the TCF industries that we are opposed to the creation of a Development Authority, as proposed by the legislation, which will have powers to implement and administer the Government's plan but no powers to do anything real for the industries if there is a need for the safety mechanism to operate. The Authority may only report and advise; it will not be able to take any real action. It is for those reasons that the Opposition will oppose the Bill at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great care to Senator Lewis's contribution to the debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill. I might say at the outset that I am disappointed that the Opposition has taken it upon itself to oppose the Bill at the second reading stage, despite the very comprehensive alterations of which notice has been given by the Government. In my opening comments I wish to address a couple of matters that Senator Lewis raised. A couple of minutes ago he referred to the efficiency of the industry. I do not argue with that specifically, but there are huge inefficiencies in many factories in the industry. The issue is not confined to workers' wages. It is about time that members of the Opposition benches got off the tack of continuing to attack the living standards of workers in this country. They have picked a very poor mark on this occasion because they would know that wages in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry are about 28 per cent below the average paid in the manufacturing industry generally. As all honourable senators would know, that is not a very highly paid area either. It is unfortunate that that furphy has been tossed into the debate tonight. There is no doubt that there are many entrepreneurs in the industry who have sought to get into the marketplace, to capture it for themselves and to compete with imports from Third World countries. Some have done a very good job, but others have sat back and enjoyed the protection offered through the various tariffs available to the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of tariffs-Senator Lewis also spoke about tariffs-is a cause of concern to me. There have been a number of rumours in the media that the Government intends to cut tariffs across the board, perhaps in the May economic statement or in the Budget Statement which is due in August this year. It would be unfortunate for the textiles, clothing and footwear industry if that came about. Across the board tariff cuts may be good for the economy and for bolstering the confidence of international money markets, but they would hit sectors of Australian industry. We have historical examples of across the board tariff cuts and we know the consequences they had on a number of industries, particularly the manufacturing industry. Certainly, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry was one of those industries hit. I am sure that honourable senators present will know that I am referring to at least one decision made during the life of the Whitlam Government to bring down an across the board tariff cut. I hope that the Government will see fit to examine closely the ramifications of such an across the board tariff cut, if indeed the media reports are true and the Government is looking at that.

What we have in this industry, together with a number of others, are plans that are evolved specifically for those industries. Those industries need to have confidence in the future. The majority of the industries which we have talked about, such as the steel industry-Senator Lewis did not mention the heavy engineering industry, but he certainly mentioned steel-the shipbuilding industry and so forth need to have confidence in the future. We cannot have a plan evolved in one year and then changed by across the board measures the next year. That will not do anything to assist the confidence of the industry or the future of that industry.

Senator Cook's second reading speech outlined in detail the objectives of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988. It is not my intention here and now to repeat those matters because I think that we get too much repetition in this chamber. I merely seek to give a background to the history of the Bill before us tonight. In 1982 the Industries Assistance Commission, commonly known as the IAC or colloquially known, in some circles, as the industry assassination commission, reported to the Federal Government on the state of the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries. The IAC came to the conclusion that the trade protection measures enjoyed by the TCF industries were severely hampering the ability of other sectors of Australian manufacturing to compete internationally. This was something that the industries concerned did not deny. This Bill in itself is a recognition of the agreement in the TCF industries that change was not only inevitable but also necessary.

At this point I would like to give credit to all sides of the industry-to the manufacturers, the owners of the enterprises we are talking about, the Government, the various Government committees and boards that investigated the industry, the trade unions and the workers on the job-for the job they have done in reaching a rational solution to the problems that are confronting them now and those that will confront them in the future. They had to do this. It was a must, because adoption of the recommendations of the IAC could have meant the death of the TCF industry in Australia.

We need to look at what the IAC recommended. It suggested that tariffs be cut by 50 per cent by 1996. It suggested that there be no labour adjustment measures, no investment incentives, no monitoring authority and no review of the effects of the recommendations on the TCF industries. Perhaps it was as a result of reports such as that that the IAC rightly earned its colloquial description of industry assassination commission.

What would have been the result if the IAC recommendations had been implemented? I do not believe that it would be any exaggeration whatsoever to say that it would have been disastrous to the industry, to the nation and, most certainly, to the workers who depend on the industry for their livelihood. There is no question about that, because some 60,000 people would have been retrenched. With no labour adjustment programs, which was an IAC recommendation, there would be little chance of their finding re-employment. This would have been all the more tragic when we remember that the vast majority of workers in these industries are women, often of ethnic backgrounds, earning meagre wages. I have mentioned before that in the clothing industry those wages already are 28 per cent below the average in the manufacturing industry. These are women whose only income is what they get from employment in this industry. Their income is only enough to keep their heads above water and in many cases their wages are used to support single income families.

Confronted by these possibilities, workers in the industry launched a massive campaign against the IAC recommendations. They took to the streets and marched. They attended rallies. They approached their local members and senators. Possibly most importantly, they themselves put forward a rational, alternative strategy. They did not just rely on slogans; they went out and investigated the situation for themselves and came up with recommendations which they themselves knew would hurt them as well as their employers and the Government. However, they knew that something had to be done. The strategy they evolved did not call for an increase in protection. It did not even demand a retention of the present rates of protection. It called for manageable change, not the inevitable chaos implicit in the IAC recommendations. The basis of the unions' alternative strategy was: one, a 75 per cent out of quota rate of duty to be phased in, over seven years, by 1996; two, a comprehensive package of work force arrangements; three, investment incentives within the industry development agreements; four, a monitoring authority; and, five, a review of how the plan was working before the end of the plan.

I think that most of us would agree, certainly those of us in this chamber, that the proposals were sensible, unselfish and reasonable. The result of their presentation is the alternative strategy before us today. The Government did not accept everything that the unions put forward, so it cannot be accused of kowtowing again to the union movement. It did not accept everything. One of the things the Government did not accept was the union proposal for a 75 per cent out of quota rate of duty. Instead, it accepted a 60 per cent rate.

Many of the unions' recommendations are embodied in the Bill. Firstly, the proposed Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority is required to monitor and implement the Government's strategy for the industry. As Senator Cook's second reading speech stated, this Authority will be required to report to the Government on the success of the strategy by 1992. Although it sounds a long time in the future, it certainly is not. The Authority must also report annually to the Parliament. In line with the intention of making the organisation flexible, it can also report to the Minister, either on its own volition or on his request.

Secondly, the Government has instituted a number of incentives to enable the industry to become more effective and competitive. The incentives mean that the firms in the industries which can show a genuine commitment to the strategy in terms of increased production of exports and import replacement, which is, of course, all-important, and of increased processing of raw materials will have a real chance of succeeding. As an aside, the amount of processing of raw materials in this country is pretty deplorable. I am sure that with a will and the successful culmination of this plan and the establishment of this Authority this side of things will certainly increase. If there is a general increase in the competitiveness of the overall industry such firms will also have a real chance of succeeding.

Thirdly, the Government has accepted the great need for labour adjustment measures. All participants in the industries are aware that undoubtedly there will be job losses as a result of the implementation of this strategy. This is something that the Government is not necessarily proud of. We do not believe in putting people out on the streets, but it is inevitable in some industries. Change happens; it cannot be stopped. Our Government has a great commitment to training. With such a commitment we could not permit retrenchments without providing the means for those retrenched workers to find alternative employment.

There are four aspects of the labour adjustment assistance package, all of which are available to workers who have been employed in the industry for at least 20 hours a week for 24 weeks or more out of the last six months. Firstly, retraining: retrenched TCF workers will be immediately eligible for labour market training for 12 months. Workers can enter a program within 12 months of being retrenched. They will be provided with income support of $100 a week. This will not be means tested on the family income. Married women will be eligible and it will not affect a spouse's social security payment.

The program will receive high publicity through the ethnic media and community organisations and Outreach, and specialist Commonwealth Employment Service staff will be recruited to provide advanced information to workers of the availability of the scheme as well as dealing sympathetically and expertly with the applications. The program will also include English language training, which is vital to so many workers in these industries.

Secondly, I wish to deal with re-employment. Immediate re-employment through Jobstart is an alternative to retraining. For employment in industries outside TCF, the new employer will receive a wage subsidy for six months of $75 a week for 18-to 20-year-olds, $100 a week for 21-to 44-year-olds, and $125 a week for those over 45. This is in line with Government recognition that older unemployed people have greater difficulty in finding employment and are, therefore, in the greatest danger of becoming long term unemployed statistics. It will be possible for a retrenched worker to mix retraining and Jobstart up to a maximum of 12 months. For example, a worker may undertake formal training for six months, then present himself as a Jobstart worker for a further six months.

Thirdly, let me deal with relocation. The relocation assistance scheme will be modified for TCF workers. Assistance of $1,500 for renting or buying a home will be available within 12 months of relocation. The fourth point I wish to make refers to delivery mechanisms. Small and mobile retrenchment teams will provide advice and assistance to retrenched workers. Where a significant number of retrenchments are to take place, a re-employment committee with union and employer representatives may be set up to establish and implement a re-employment program. There is, thus, a great mood of confidence in the TCF industries. As the Minister has informed the Senate, it is very encouraging that a number of firms have already undertaken major investment programs since the announcement of the strategy. Just as encouraging, in my opinion, is that workers who face retrenchment have a very real chance of finding re-employment.

It is also encouraging that the overall strategy will drastically reduce the number of workers who find themselves in this position than would have been the case if the Government had adopted the IAC proposals. While there will be a decline in the number of workers through improvements in productivity, and while some workers who leave their jobs will not be replaced, jobs will be created in the new areas of investment that are part of the strategy-for example, raw material processing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?
—The raw material processing side of things.
—Such as?
—Such as leather goods, for example.
—Leather goods?

—Yes. The Minister and other speakers have already referred to the specific aspects of the four programs under the strategy-that is, raw material processing, industries efficiency, industries infrastructure and export development programs. I do not intend to go into these in any detail, but I believe that they constitute a very positive step towards making our TCF industries efficient and internationally competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister referred to the fact that the success of the strategy is dependent on the ability of the Authority to change attitudes and practices. While I agree that changes must occur in these areas, I think it should be recognised that the participants in the TCF industries have already proved their willingness and enthusiasm for the strategy. Without this enthusiasm on the part of the workers, for instance, we would not be here talking about the TCF Development Authority. Unions have admitted that the strategy cannot guarantee the future of any particular firm, industry sector or region. No level of industry protection could do this either. What the strategy can do, however, is give firms and workers a fighting chance, at the same time easing the burden on other sectors of Australian manufacturing.

The high levels of protection have not ultimately been to the benefit of workers in the TCF industries. The most highly assisted industries have shown some of the poorest returns to the stake holders. I mention again for the third time, because I think it is worth reinforcing, that the average wage in the clothing industry is 28 per cent below that applicable to all of the manufacturing sector. But to have adopted the Industries Assistance Commission proposal would have meant the death of the industries. These days, once an industry dies in this country it is very difficult to regenerate that industry.

In conclusion, I congratulate the unions on their approach to the problems that confronted them on behalf of their membership. I again congratulate the Government on the approach that it took in developing the plan and the Authority, which is the subject of this Bill. I congratulate members of the Government's Caucus committee and the specific subcommittee from the industry committee under the chairmanship of the now Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, who put in a lot of work, effort and consultation in bringing people together in order to come forth with some consensus approach to a very difficult situation which confronted workers.

I do not think it would serve any purpose in again appealing to the Opposition to reconsider its opposition to the Bill. But I ask the Opposition to have another look at the Government's amendments that have been circulated in the chamber. For what it is worth, I ask the Opposition to do that so that hopefully we can proceed down a path that will be in the interests of the workers in the TCF industries, in the interests of the States and the regional areas where the TCF factories are established and, ultimately, in the interests of the nation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was a little puzzled this evening when Senator Lewis addressed us on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988. The honourable senator seemed to begin by saying that he was in favour of the Bill and then concluded by saying that he was going to oppose it. The Bill proposes the establishment of a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority for the purposes of better managing and restructuring this significant industry which is potentially of much greater significance to Australia. I think, in view of what Senator Lewis said, it is worthwhile pointing out that the industry itself is quite strongly in favour of this Bill. Perhaps the industry will be quite disappointed to hear that the Opposition, I take it, is actually going to oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I have in front of me a letter from Mr Keith Purcell, who is the Executive Director of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia Ltd. Among other things, he says:
We believe it is important that an authority with monitoring and administrative functions be established for the purposes of effectively implementing the Post 1988 TCF Sectoral Plan.
On balance, we regard it as most important that the Authority be legislated for and would be concerned if the legislation was rejected.
He goes on:

As mentioned to you, we attach particular importance to the safeguard mechanism which is referred to in the Minister's Second Reading Speech. Sections 3(2) and 12 seem to provide for safeguard action to be taken if that becomes necessary. Accordingly you will appreciate the importance we attach to the passage of this legislation.
He further goes on:

Without detracting from this `on-balance' position, we consider it would be desirable if powers such as those set out in Sections 46, 47, 49, 51 and 53 were deleted from the legislation or appropriately amended. It is our understanding that Senator Button is agreeable to this.

Honourable senators will know that in fact the Government has agreed to do just that so that any substantial objection which the industry had to this Bill in its original form has now been quite adequately addressed by the Government. Having said that, one may have a bad Bill which is supported by the industry for reasons which may relate to the industry's inability to understand exactly what the Bill does or which is bad in some other respect. But I do not believe that this Bill falls into this category, so the Australian Democrats will be supporting it.

There are a few matters we would like to raise with the Senate. They relate first of all to something which Senator Lewis said in relation to the hands-off approach that he was extolling. The second reading speech of Senator Cook for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) mentions that in the case of wool-I remind the Senate that Australia is one of the world's major wool producers-only 5 per cent is processed in this country and, in the case of cotton, only 10 per cent is processed in this country. I was not aware, but I will take the Minister's word for it, that we are also a producer of high grade cotton. One might note in passing that the cotton area in New South Wales happens to be one of the most heavily contaminated with organochlorin pesticides in the world and many people have been poisoned in that area. Leaving that aside, apparently we produce high quality cotton of which only 10 per cent is processed in this country. As honourable senators will know, the processing of hides into leather and the further processing into high quality goods is carried out in this country to a very small extent.

That is the situation that we have with an industry which has been operating largely under a free enterprise competitive system. It has brought us to a situation in which we export large amounts of unprocessed primary products and then import back the finished goods to be made up into suits, clothing and leatherwear. I find it difficult to believe that with a Development Authority such as that outlined in this Bill and with the combination of planning and guidance by such an Authority, and by the Government, together with private industry, if intelligently conceived, cannot do better than that. There is no a priori reason why an unfettered free enterprise system should serve the interests of a country. The idea of Adam Smith-that somehow or other an invisible hand is going to guide competitive greed towards serving the common good-has certainly been around for a long time, but that is merely an assertion and it should have been laid to rest long since.

Moreover, there is abundant evidence that, again from purely theoretical considerations, the competitive system does not continue for very long but tends rapidly towards a monopoly. That can be shown in mathematical models quite easily. One needs only to look at what has happened in practice. The market-again, quite quickly-tends towards a monopoly situation in which the common interest is not served. So I believe that the guidance of a Development Authority such as that outlined in this Bill will serve Australia better. Hopefully, it will get a lot more of the processing of raw materials into value added goods within this country.

The Bill is divided into areas to which the Authority will be directing its attention as outlined a moment ago. As to the processing of raw materials, there is again no particular emphasis in the Bill on increasing the value of raw materials produced in Australia. One hopes that that will be a high priority. The industry's efficiency program is provided for in division 2, the industry's infrastructure is dealt with in division 4 and the export development program is covered in division 3. As to the export development program, I again lay emphasis on the desirability of import replacement, which was briefly mentioned in the second reading speech. It seems to me that far too little attention is given to it in our national policy. I believe that a great deal more can be done by increasing the efficiency of the use of items within Australia and replacing imports. I emphasise that that is a far more effective and cheaper road to take than to go into foreign countries and compete on markets with which we are not necessarily familiar. I point out that, while this is clearly mentioned in the Bill, it does not develop that point particularly broadly.

Nor does the Bill lay much emphasis on the training and retraining of people within the industry. This is not left out of the Bill in the sense that it can come within the purview of the Development Authority, but neither is it specifically mentioned. I would like the Bill to have placed greater emphasis on that matter as a responsibility of the Authority. It is not brought out as one of the specific areas for attention and highlighted as an area to which the Authority should address its concerns. Quite clearly, as this industry adopts new technology there will be a need for a great deal of retraining within the industry and, to the extent that workers are displaced and find other work in either this industry or elsewhere, retraining or further training will be required.

I would now like briefly to discuss clauses 54 and 58, which are the clauses dealing with sanctions to be brought against those who infringe an aspect of the Act, as it will be. Honourable senators will note that clause 54 provides in the case of a natural person for a penalty of $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months or both; and, in the case of a body corporate, $5,000. The point I wish to raise is a general one. I choose to flag it now because I think it is one that needs a great deal more discussion in relation to a lot of legislation that goes through this place.

There is no natural connection between the penalty as expressed in dollars and the penalty as expressed in a term of imprisonment. Nobody these days, not even a person on the dole, gets as little as $1,000 in 12 months. A natural relationship between those two amounts might be the average wage, or it might be the wage which a person earns. Senator Button pointed out to me in discussion on this very point this afternoon that many of the people penalised under this legislation might be quite well off. They may earn $50,000 in 12 months. There is no natural relationship at all between a $1,000 fine and 12 months in gaol or both. These sorts of penalties mean that those who are poor go to gaol and those who can afford to pay, pay the fine. I will move later, and I will do this consistently with other legislation when it comes before me, that there should be a natural relationship between penalties. I think Senator McKiernan would support me in this. Working on an average income of, say, $20,000 a year, if one regards a fine of $1,000 as adequate, the gaol term might be as little as two weeks. That would be a fair relationship.

In further support of that, I draw attention to the pictures which appeared on tonight's television of the lad in New South Wales who went to gaol for non-payment of a fine and who is now essentially a human vegetable with very serious brain damage from which he almost certainly will never completely recover. I also point to the excellent Australian Broadcasting Corporation program of a few months ago on Australian gaols and imprisonment which pointed out that the early term of imprisonment is the significant one and that extending terms of imprisonment does not necessarily serve any further useful purpose. I point out also, of course, that in the case of a corporation the penalty of $5,000 bears no relationship to the fine of $1,000 for an individual-that that really is quite a minuscule amount for a corporation.

Finally, I would like to point to an issue raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I do not think it was mentioned by Senator Lewis. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has raised the question whether the delegation of power provision contained in this Bill is too wide; in other words, the Authority is given the power to delegate authority and there is no requirement that the person to whom the power is delegated need have any particular qualification. Clause 66 (1) (c) goes so far as to state that, with the approval of the Minister, authority may be delegated to any other person or body-in other words, any person at all. The only check in there is the ministerial approval which is required. If the Minister is sufficiently careful about assessing these things when they pass across his desk, I guess that that is some sort of safeguard. I take it that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did not regard that as necessarily a sufficient safeguard and flagged it for the attention of the Senate. I think we should perhaps look at that when we get into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, detailed in the second reading speech delivered for him by Senator Cook the perceived effects that the establishment of this Authority will have on the industry and the benefits that are designed to follow. I believe that these benefits are largely illusory. Senator McKiernan, in responding to a question that I asked, indicated that there would be further jobs in leather processing. I know that the Government is very keen to increase the volume of scouring in this country, but I would like to remind the Government that there is already an oversupply in that area. I believe that a lot of the benefits that allegedly will occur as a result of the restructuring of this industry and the new jobs that will be found will not be in the raw material processing area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us tonight merely defers a political decision that must inevitably take place in the 1990s. This Bill will have the effect of just deferring a problem until the 1990s. The industry seems to be quite happy with that deferral. I am not sure whether it will really be in the best interests of Australia, or even in the best interests of the industries under consideration, merely to act as an intermediate step. I believe that all this legislation is doing is creating that situation. However, I would like to acknowledge that the Government has gone quite a long way towards removing some of the problems that we highlighted earlier in regard to the extent of the powers with which the Authority was endowed. I thank both the shadow Minister, Senator Lewis, and Senator Button for agreeing to those sorts of amendments. I feel sure that these amendments will be welcomed by the industry. Obviously, they will also be welcomed by the legal authorities who were concerned about the repressive nature of those original provisions which have now been withdrawn.

The functions of the Authority include the monitoring of the volume and the value of local production; the production costs in the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries; the changes in industry employment levels; the level of direction of investment in those industries, both in terms of Australian equity and Australian TCF investment abroad; and the productivity improvements, especially in regard to catering for the export market. However, I believe that there are compelling reasons in our present economic climate for a reduction of government expenditure. Therefore, the Government's desire to create yet another statutory authority to oversee the implementation of the plan is not particularly compatible with that aim. I believe and people on my side of politics believe that the monitoring of the plan can be adequately carried out by Senator Button's Department. The Liberal Party of Australia has indicated that, in government, this could easily occur. That implies that, in government, we would provide adequate resources directed towards meeting that undertaking. All Senator Button really had to do was to give a commitment to the Parliament and to the industry that there would be adequate resources within his Department to monitor the plan properly and carry out all the work of that Authority.

I believe that the plan could be monitored in a most cost-effective, efficient and appropriate fashion by Senator Button's Department, particularly if he was prepared to give this resource commitment, as the Liberal Party is prepared to do. I feel sure that all parties would be far better served because, after all, the Department can work a lot quicker than a statutory corporation if things go wrong. It has much more ready access to the Minister's ear; and it does not have to rely on formalities, red tape or the production of reports. I am also concerned that some of the people who may be appointed to the TCF Authority may be overcommitted to the restructuring of the industry. We have heard Senator McKiernan acknowledge tonight that there will be restructuring. There will be substantial job losses; it will not just be a case of natural attrition. Factories will close and there will be a redirection of that investment.

Employers and the unions, in agreeing to the plan, have acknowledged that the industry will have to undergo some fairly dramatic changes if the implementation of the plan progresses. I suppose that one of the redeeming features of the plan-it is only an intermediate feature-is this safety net provision that if the industry contracts at too fast a rate a process will be put into effect. I suggest that the monitoring of the plan by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, which I believe is more attuned to the needs and problems of the industry, would result in a more sensitive appraisal of the impact of the plan upon the industry.

I think an appraisal by a statutory authority tends to be rather impersonal and slow; it is not as sensitive as an appraisal the Department could well do. I believe that the Department would have a greater commitment to the ongoing wellbeing of the industry than an independent quango that could walk away from the plan after it was implemented and have no further ties to the industry. As I said earlier, the Department is naturally closer to the Minister and is more likely to ensure the survival of the basic components of the industry. I therefore have some doubts that the proposed Authority will be in a position to achieve its stated objectives. After all, it can only report to the Minister if the impact of the plan is having an adverse effect on the industry-and the numbers have been spelt out in the plan-which will result in the contraction of TCF operations ahead of the agreed schedule. If this happens, the plan may be suspended for 12 months and the matter referred to the Industries Assistance Commission. I add a word of warning because, given the attitude of the Industries Assistance Commission to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, the conclusions in its report are not likely to be very supportive of the industry.

The Authority, therefore, under its present charter appears to provide a very much short term solution or a palliative to the problems the industry may face as it progresses. I suspect that those people who are interested in the preservation of the industry, albeit in a smaller and more viable form, would naturally have to agree with me on this issue. The Authority appears to have gained a measure of acceptance in the absence of a more suitable alternative. This Authority virtually has been forced upon the industry on a take it or leave it basis. Even under these circumstances I still think there are good grounds for supporting the Opposition's contention that the establishment of the TCF Development Authority to oversee and monitor the implementation of the plan is therefore unnecessary. I submit, however, that there is a real need for an informed source that will work with industry and will have the capacity to liaise constantly with the Minister and to act promptly for the benefit of the TCF industry where necessary. Therefore, one could not just hand this monitoring authority to another body such as the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council Ltd because it would lack the teeth and commitment.

This industry differs from other industries which come under particular plans or authorities, namely, the Automotive Industry Authority or the Steel Industry Authority, because the TCF industry has a multitude of players. So good communication is not always easily or readily achievable. A concerted effort must be made to ensure that the communication lines are fluid enough to allow expeditious action where necessary. I do not believe that an authority gives this quick line of communication as closely as a department would. Closer links between the industry and the Minister will be very important during the implementation of the plan. As I mentioned earlier, the Department has the capability to fulfil and could well fulfil this function provided it is given adequate resources.

This Bill before us tonight is the first tangible evidence in the Parliament of the TCF plan which has now been around for something like 18 months. It would have been more appropriate if it had been presented when the plan was announced in, say, June 1987 or thereabouts although I know we were not sitting at that time. But a lot of time has intervened since that announcement. The Minister said in his second reading speech that it should be read in conjunction with the statement on the TCF plan which was made to the Senate on 5 June 1987. So I will include in my remarks some comments on that plan.

Senator Cook's second reading speech was largely an outline of the work of the proposed Authority. But there is one sentence hidden away on page 6 which I regret that Senator McKiernan did not comment on because that reference on page 6 is most alarming. I would have thought that Senator McKiernan, as a good union man, should have been aware of that provision. If he had read it, it brings shame on him that he did not draw attention to the problems that could give to the industry. Being a good union man, he should join with some of his union colleagues and be somewhat appalled at the temerity of the Minister to include those remarks on page 6 of his second reading speech. I would like to quote them:
I should say however that the industries cannot expect the plan to be immutable and that industry planning should take into account other factors such as macro-economic circumstances.

That is an extraordinary statement when the whole basis of the plan is to create some certainty in the minds of those people who are investing millions of dollars in new technology, getting state of the art machinery and entering into new export markets. What a new exporter does not want is to find suddenly that the rules to the plan have been changed. Senator Button is giving notice to the industry and saying, `Look out industry. We are prepared to change the game rules after the game has started'.

In other words, Senator Button is saying, `Here is the TCF plan. This is what the Government wants the TCF industries to aim towards and yet we might change the plan at any time because of perceived so-called economic circumstances'. There is a concern in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry that the Government will introduce some cuts in assistance in the May economic statement. This concern already has severely undermined the effectiveness of the plan and the confidence of the industry in the Government's intention. I am surprised that Senator Coulter did not refer to this matter. Despite the fact, which the Minister accepts in the first paragraph on page 6, that the industries are accepting the reduction in assistance and responding to the resulting changes in a positive manner, he is cutting the ground from under their feet.

The TCF plan makes provision for a review. But I am most interested in what Senator Button would regard as the macro-economic circumstances. There is a real danger perceived in the industries, both by management and the unions, that the Hawke Government will use the macro-economic bluff to slash assistance regardless of the success of the TCF plan and of the expensive restructuring that is going on to accommodate that plan. The blame for this eerie vagueness in the Minister's speech cannot be laid entirely at his feet.

It is clear on this side of the chamber and also in TCF circles that some senior Cabinet Ministers are keen to slash assistance to the TCF sector and to other industries. They are the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden). They are pressing Senator Button into agreeing to further and more immediate cuts to the TCF sectors to satisfy their specious macro-economic master plan, completely discounting the improved competitiveness of the industry and the hundreds of thousands of people who have been employed in this sector.

It took one Labor government, led by Gough Whitlam, to all but destroy that industry. I fervently hope that it is not another Labor administration that ignorantly completes the job. Senator Button has received bipartisan support for endeavouring to improve the competitiveness of the TCF sector. It would be tragic if a split in the Cabinet led by economic and trade Ministers, who do not really appreciate the complexity or fragility of the industries, leads to further cuts. I ask Labor Party members to take that back to their Caucus. On 28 November 1986 I asked a question of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, concerning the mooted Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. I will repeat that question. I asked him first whether:

. . . the production contraction safeguards of 15 per cent for the industries overall and 10 per cent, 20 per cent and 20 per cent respectively for the textile, clothing and footwear sectors are central elements of the plan?
He replied yes. Secondly, I asked whether the new Authority would:
. . . closely monitor developments and anticipate any need for policy revisions designed to ensure that the maximum production contraction provisions of the plan are not exceeded?

Honourable senators will note in that question about policy revisions that he would anticipate any need. He said yes. We intend to hold him to that answer because the emphasis there was on anticipating moves rather than on waiting for event to occur.

Thirdly, I asked the Minister to ensure that the Authority was provided with adequate resources to meet its vitally important role and that it be composed of appropriately qualified and experienced people. Again, the Minister replied yes. I am repeating these questions and the unequivocal replies by the Minister for two purposes: first, to remind the Senate what the Minister said and, secondly, to remind the Minister that he made a clear commitment not only to assistance levels but also that the new authority would be able to anticipate policy revisions required by changed circumstances. I call on the Minister to reaffirm this anticipatory element of the TCF plan in the light of his worrying general remarks about immutability of the plan in his more recent speech.

I ask the Senate: Is the Minister trying to ease the Government away from its previously more responsible stance to a new position in order that assistance can be slashed? I am sure that many executives in the industries and factory workers-particularly those in New South Wales this week-would welcome a clear affirmation of the hitherto consistent application of the plan from the Hawke Government.

In the context of this Bill I turn to a general speculation, which the Government has done little to damp down, regarding across-the-board reductions in assistance, not only to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, but also generally. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries have responded positively to meet the objectives of Senator Button's new plan. In 1986-87 new capital expenditure on buildings, plant and equipment increased to more than $232m and is expected to reach more than $283m this financial year-an increase of 22 per cent. That is quite a remarkable achievement. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries were assured, firstly, that action taken in the multilateral trade negotiations would take into account and be consistent with domestic industry objectives and, secondly, that references made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to phased elimination of quotas would be consistent with the new TCF program. With this background, it would not be responsible for the Government to take further action to reduce assistance, despite the course that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Treasury might be urging their respective Ministers to pursue, particularly because of attitudes limited to their own departmental objectives and not in keeping with consistent national economic growth.

Industries other than those in the TCF sector should also be concerned about Senator Button's comments about the TCF plan not being immutable. This is because assistance for the chemical industry, the paper industry, the electronics sector and the communications industries was all determined after the fall in the value of the Australian dollar and they too, like TCF, should be protected by the Minister from any further cuts. There was certainly an argument before the realignment of the currencies. My comments are made in view of the fact that all industry assistance was determined after the realignment of the currencies and therefore there should not be further cuts.

There is little evidence that the major TCF trading nations-the United States of America and the nations of the European Economic Community-are committed to any real action to dismantle or even reduce their quotas in the long term, and so the cuts which have been sought by the Australian Government and accepted positively by the Australian textiles, clothing and footwear industries make our producers even more vulnerable to trade pressure. This is further evidence that more cuts would be totally irresponsible. TCF industries representatives have expressed their concerns to the Government and also to the Opposition about unfair trading practices. The Government approach to the TCF sector, encompassed in the plan, relies on fair trading. There is grave concern in these industries that as the tariff quotas are reduced and eventually removed, and other assistance is downgraded, unfair trading practices will seriously undermine the Government's objectives. There is an important need for anti-dumping machinery, with the force of legislation of this Parliament, which will be not only efficient but also effective. Although this is not part of the current legislation, it is appropriate to raise these concerns and seek the Minister's view on the Government's attitude towards re-establishing such anti-dumping provisions without delay.
Senator Cook in his second reading speech made some remarks about the attitudes in the industry. I quote:

. . . the Authority's major function will be to administer the industries development strategy in a coordinated and cost effective manner, as it is the strategy which will promote those changes in attitudes necessary to the reinvigoration of the industries.

The Senate should be reminded that the industries have been built up by private money and private expertise, and that it is investment, technical and managerial skills, production and marketing expertise, the skills and commitment of the work force, and fashion design anticipation and judgment which sustain TCF industries' existence-not handouts from this Federal Government or any other government. Unfortunately it is becoming popular for the Minister and several of his colleagues, notably the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, to don their `hair shirts' and say that Australian industry is hopeless and they have such a huge task to make it work. This argument is becoming tired and worn, if it ever had any application-apart from political rhetoric-and attention should be drawn to certain facts: 95 per cent of clothing comes from developing countries which have a huge low wage cost competitive advantage. There is a very significant and growing capital investment in the Australian TCF industry, despite the reductions in tariff quotas, and no similar steps have been taken by overseas competitors.
