For example, Pacific Dunlop's Holeproof division last month demonstrated its continuing confidence in the Australian garment making industry when it opened a new factory in Victoria. It must be remembered that conditions have been difficult for the TCF industries for some time. The devaluation of the Australian dollar has been of little benefit to the industries because, while the Australian dollar has gone down against the US dollar, the German mark, the yen and the Swiss franc, we have not devalued against the currencies of Taiwan and other countries which export textiles and related goods to Australia. These currencies have gone down as Australia's currency has gone down. The efforts of the industries in weathering the storm have been commendable and it is time that the Government acknowledged its commitment to their future economic efficiency.

In conclusion, I would say that the Government had the general thrust of the TCF plan right, but it is using the wrong mechanisms to implement it. The Government is also undermining the effectiveness of the plan by saying in the second reading speech that it is not immutable. The establishment of yet another statutory authority with all the attendant costs is not necessary when the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce could carry out the same function in a more cost-effective way. I am also most concerned about the macro-economic caveat that has been placed across the legislation by the Minister. I would be pleased if Senator Button, in his further comments to the Senate, would reaffirm the integrity of the plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, which supports the principle of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan, is simply concerned about the need in this Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill for yet another quango to administer this plan. The Opposition takes the view that there are already so many quangos around with so many powers that have not performed adequately that this is not an appropriate method to use in implementing the proposals generally to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in Australia. The Opposition totally supports the view that there is a need for the industry to be encouraged to restructure and to become more competitive internationally. That does not deny that in many instances the companies in these industries have gone down the right track. In recent times there has been an increase in exports as a result of some of the more alert and competitive companies adopting the sort of approach that both the Government and the Opposition favour.

SPEECH.PARA: The big question is the extent to which government intervention by way of this proposed quango is the ideal way to go about it. The case against the quango has been stated by Senator Lewis. Clearly, it would be another burdensome and expensive mechanism. One can look at the steel industry plan to see how the best of intentions can be defeated by the failure of one participant in the plan to stick by his obligations under it. Without dealing too much with the comparable situation in the steel industry, I would like to point out that despite the existence of the steel industry plan since 1984, productivity has been down continually in the steel industry at levels totally unacceptable. The industry is no more competitive-in fact it has become less competitive over recent years than it was before the beginning of the plan. The Government says that there is a special reason for that: it is due to the technical problems that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) has had with some of the new items of plant and equipment and the No. 4 blast furnace at Port Kembla where some of these major problems have arisen.

The point is, and it cannot be argued, I believe, that that plan created obligations for various participants. There was an obligation on the Government-that is on the taxpayer-to provide large amounts of bounty. There was an obligation on the company to provide large amounts-multimillions of dollars-in investment in new plant and equipment and at the same time there was an obligation on the unions to abide by dispute-settling agreements. We all know that the unions thumbed their noses at that. Despite the cheerful sounds being made today by Senator Button in response to a dorothy dix question about the expected improvement in productivity at Australian Iron and Steel at Port Kembla, what Senator Button clearly and carefully omitted from his response was that BHP is only confident about its productivity increasing if in fact there is no return to the levels of industrial disruption which have been a feature of this industry ever since the plan gave a feeling of protection to the unions, to enable them to misbehave behind the screen of a governmental plan of a government authority. That is exactly what has happened.

I believe it would be disastrous if the unions in the textiles industry, for example, were to take the view that because there is a plan involving considerable investment both by the Government and by the companies, that this should be some kind of protective device behind which the unions could then use any tactics to increase their share of the cake. The fact is that unless this plan works, unless this industry can be made even more competitive, there will not be a cake at all. What I am massively disheartened about is that at Port Kembla we have seen the risk of the company ceasing any further investment because of the disgraceful industrial relations record since this plan began. I would be most concerned if that experience were to be reflected because of the existence of this plan in the textiles industry.

I should mention that probably this week an interesting judgment will be handed down on a dispute at Port Kembla which could once again result in further industrial disruption. I hope it will not but it seems to me there is no guarantee that participation in this kind of industry restructuring scheme in which the Government plays a key role is of necessity a guarantee that all participants in the industry will pull their weight. Of course, as many of these textile companies are in regional centres where the industrial relations record has been good, there may be a better chance of this scheme not being sabotaged by disruptive union practices. I must say, I hope that is so.

The reality, in our view, is that instead of having another quango like the one proposed in this legislation, we could have an industry advisory committee that could provide the consultation and monitoring mechanisms envisaged by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council or that body could even do it as part of its norman activities. In addition, it is quite clear that this new body will involve the duplication of functions, including overlapping with the functions of the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council. There is no reason, it seems to me, why departmental officers could not administer the grant of financial assistance involved in this legislation, particularly as other external bodies like the Australian Industry Development Corporation are checking the viability of business plans as part of the sectoral plan. In any event, departmental staff will continue to monitor overseas developments. I wonder whether the desire for the establishment of the authority as a quango is a statement of the lack of confidence in the ability of departmental staff, and other people involved in governmental roles in this industry, to monitor developments in Australia.

The whole response by the Opposition to this proposal is one of support limited only by its opposition to the quango. I remind the Senate what Senator Messner said in June last year in a very brief response because he did not have much time to study the details of the plan at the time. When the proposal was outlined generally by Senator Button on 5 June 1987, Senator Messner while outlining the general support had this to say:

We note that the Government has brought forward the planned reduction of the tariff from 1988 to 1992 in a very significant fashion. It will be a substantial change. Of course, we in the Opposition have supported the principle of phased, gradual and predictable change in the tariff structure. Consequently, this would fit into our normal approach to such changes. However, I have to note that there does not appear to be any accompanying relief for business from the cost burdens imposed on it as a result of this Government's taxes. We note the existence still of things like the fringe benefits tax which have imposed enormous cost on businesses operating not only in this area but also generally. If the Government is serious about reducing tariffs and protection, it ought also to be serious about reducing the burdens on industry. One of those burdens is the taxes it has introduced in recent times.

Of course, Senator Messner, by mentioning the level of tax that has to be paid, also noted the high rate of corporate tax in Australia compared with corporate taxes overseas. I agree with everything that Senator Messner said at the time. It seems to me that if there were a more competitive tax structure in Australia, that would do much more to help industries such as these than would creating yet another quango with powers to intervene and, it has been held, powers to influence the structure of the industry significantly. As was pointed out earlier by Senator Lewis, the Authority originally was to have draconian powers, which were reduced, as I understand it, only as a result of strong pressure from the Opposition. Certainly there are other things I should like to see being done to improve the competitiveness of the clothing, footwear and textile industries in Australia-basically changes relating to costs imposed by the Government on this industry. Of course, it is not only governments that impose these dreadful pressures on this industry. There is also the considerable problem of continuing cost rises of other production factors, such as labour. This industry is one of those that clearly demonstrate that if their employees are to continue to demand the maintenance of their standard of living, either their jobs will be destroyed, or the rest of the community will have to pay an increasing proportion of wages to employees, either by way of direct government assistance or tariff protection. That will add severely, significantly and increasingly to the cost burden on the rest of the community to benefit the employees in these particular industries.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table, subject to the Minister's sighting the document, which I must say I have not had the opportunity to raise with him. It is prepared by Werner International, Brussels, and sets out the ratios of hourly labour costs in the primary textile industry in a group of countries including Australia, the United States of America, Japan and others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—Subject to seeing the document, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: INTERNATIONAL COMPARISONS OF HOURLY LABOUR COSTS

TALK.START.PARA: —The table demonstrates that Australia's ratios of hourly labour costs in the primary textile industry had by 1984 become worse than all of our main trading partners, with the exception of the United States of America, although not by a disastrous amount. However, of interest is the ratio of our new competitors. For example, China had a ration of three, as against 100 for Australia. So, Australia will face major competitive problems, particularly with the newly emergent industrialised countries of Asia, with whom it is absolutely vital that we maintain friendly relations. I acknowledge that this is a major problem. Whilst stressing that it underlines the need for restraint in seeking continuing increases in rates of pay, there is no doubt that the figures in the incorporated table demonstrate quite clearly that even if there were massive restraint-I am sure the Minister would be aware of this-the differentials are so enormous that Australia would still be at a massive disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not pretending that wage restraint is the only factor, or that it will bring some automatic success in this area. All that I am stressing is that the figures clearly show the sort of pressures and problems that the industry in Australia inevitably faces and will continue to face. Indeed, the problem will worsen if our wage rates continue to rise at a rate faster than those of our competitors.

The point has been made that wage rates in South East Asia have been increasing at a faster rate than have rates in Australia. I do not have the statistics available. Even so, it will take many years before the wage rates in South East Asia will be anywhere near the rates paid in Australia. There is no doubt that as part of the package of restraint and changed attitudes that is necessary in this industry we will have to recognise that for the industry to survive there will have to be a level of restraint with which many may feel uncomfortable and which of itself could provide a degree of restructuring.

The extent of the problem that could take place in Australia was evident at a series of meetings held in recent times in the Illawarra region, which has a considerable number of textile factories largely employing migrant women. The meetings were held to discuss concerns about future employment prospects in the industry in that region. The first meeting was held in June 1986. At those discussions the Government official said something that the Opposition strongly supports; that one of the Government's objectives was to cut back on negative measures such as quotas and tariffs, and to shift the emphasis to positive measures. The Opposition totally agrees with that and is eagerly awaiting the reduction in, for example, income tax and other taxes of various kinds imposed on the industry. That would be a positive measure. It seems extraordinary to me that we are talking about $100m or $200m being provided to assist the industry at a time when the industry must be paying hundreds of millions of dollars in taxation. I suppose it could be argued, of course, that because so many firms in the industry are not making profits, the level of corporate tax is almost immaterial.

At one of the meetings reference was made to the concern I expressed of how Australia can compete with, for example, Chinese industries which have the advantage of a relatively low wage rate. I believe it was a local textiler who asked, `How do we compete with Chinese industries which pay wages of only $37 a month?'. The response from the Government official at the meeting was, `With difficulty'. I accept that is the reality. Then the question was asked, `How can we continue to restructure when most firms already have restructured during the past seven years?'. That is a sound point. There has been an enormous volume of restructuring in the textile industry during the past years. No other group of industries other than clothing, textiles and footwear has been subjected to so many Industries Assistance Commission inquiries, and has so often been put at risk. The result has been, as I have said, enormous restructuring. The response from the Government official was that restructuring had not occurred across the board and that there was still scope for restructuring of the clothing and footwear industries in particular. This matter is of some concern because whilst it is true that many of the big groups have restructured, some of the smaller firms apparently have not. At the meeting a union official said that he believed local equipment in the Illawarra region was as modern as anywhere in the world and, in that situation, where would the restructuring take place? The clear implication was: what further restructuring can be done? The Government representative confirmed that it was only the major firms, not the smaller firms, that had been significantly involved in restructuring. One of the big firms said:

Government needs to understand the concern for the industry . . . The firms already have modern machines. There is no other way to cut costs and therefore save jobs. . . . We employ many married women and this helps many families maintain the house, car, etc. Without that income many families will need to leave the Region.

This is one of those dreadful problems. Another big manufacturer, who has three plants in the region, employs 700 people and makes 15 million garments a year, asked what will happen if the plants close down. He said that the plants will close down and move overseas if it becomes evident that they simply cannot continue. There is no doubt that in this industry one of the main things firms want is confidence in government involvement in the future. Whether it is right out or right in, they want to know. They do not want to have to hang on or not know whether to make investment decisions. Certainty of the Government's role is absolutely vital. That manufacturer said that many firms have already moved overseas. In fact, all they do is put the major firm's labels on garments which are actually made overseas. The garments still have the well-known Australian label on them. One of the manufacturers did ask about what seems to me to be one of the key problems:
Do the many industrial disputes create an atmosphere where Government has to take steps such as that now facing the TCF industries?
Certainly, something similar occurred, unsuccessfully, in the steel industry. What interested me then was that the local union leader, who has since retired, claimed:
Since the accord, the number of disputes has declined. I agree there is a need for better industrial relations; we cannot afford job losses in the region.

He wanted to set up an industry plan for settling disputes. I raise that because that was the atmosphere behind the creation of the steel industry plan. That same union leader who made the statement that he agreed there was a need for better industrial relations and who said that we cannot afford job losses in the region, nonetheless was leading, and continued to lead until his recent retirement, continuing industrial disruption destroying the effectiveness, to a large extent, of the steel industry plan. It seems to me to be absolutely vital that in these arrangements every effort should be made to lock in the related unions to any of the changes that are to be made. As I have said, the thrust of the Government's approach is totally supported by the Opposition. I quote with total approbation Senator Button's statement in June 1987:

The Government has been concerned to encourage the development of industries which are more internationally competitive and export oriented, innovative and better able to adapt to changing circumstances and capable of operating in the longer term with low levels of community support. In pursuit of these objectives industry policy is moving away from over reliance on protection as an industry assistance measure and focusing more on improving the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian industry.

I guess it is like motherhood to say that one agrees with that, but it is an ideal objective. In that context, the Opposition has agreed in general with the textiles, clothing and footwear approach. But our approval and support, as expressed by Senator Messner in June last year, in no way indicated that we favoured the creation of this interventionist authority-yet another authority. On the other hand, I suppose that we must recognise that someone has to make ultimate decisions. That is another reason why the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority does not appear to be an appropriate body. It will not make decisions. It is simply another organisation which will recommend to the Government what to do. For example, I think that its role is to recommend that the Government hold an inquiry, which I think is dealt with under clause 12 (3) of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clause 12 (3) (d). Why do we want another body which will end up recommending things when, in a sense, in several directions-at least three-we have bodies spread around which have exactly that capacity? I do not know whether having an authority is a means by which a Minister can duck responsibility for making a decision, perhaps saying, `It is an unpopular decision, but it has been recommended to me by this Authority and, therefore, somehow I am not involved in that decision making'.

SPEECH.PARA: This industry is still a major one in Australia. It employs about 120,000 people and accounts for 7 per cent of manufacturing value added. It is massively important in country or provincial areas. I believe that it is up to the Government to administer the outline of this plan. I believe that the best interests of the industry will not be served by creating yet another quango, another authority, which it seems to me, will do nothing to add to the source and range of information available to the Government on this very important industry. Of course, it is particularly important to the region in New South Wales that I seek to represent-the Illawarra region. I only hope that the restructuring that is involved in this plan will bring the sorts of benefits that both the Government and the Opposition believe will come from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. They have been diverse and, in some cases, interesting. By way of reply to the second reading debate, I will try to deal with some of the main arguments which have been put. I heard some of those arguments not in the chamber but over the magnificent system which we have here. I just want to try to put them in some perspective. Senator Michael Baume, towards the end of his speech, asked why there should be an authority, a quango. That is a question which I would quite happily ask myself in another context. I am not addicted to more quangos, more authorities. I think I am on public record as saying that the last thing I would want in this country would be wall to wall industry authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something about the textiles, clothing and footwear industry generally in relation to that. It is a very diverse, complex industry, a large employer of labour and, traditionally, highly protected. The process of unscrambling that, of simplifying the tariff structure, of trying gradually to reduce the levels of protection and dealing with the very many facets of the industry, which are very diverse, ranging from boutique shoe making to hobnail boots and Senator Puplick's bow ties to industrial overalls-the very complex questions involved in dealing with those diverse industries-I think distinguishes it considerably from other industries.

The other point I would make is that it has always been an industry in which, because of its high levels of protection and diversity, there has been a strong measure of government intervention. For example, the Fraser Government established something called the Elix Committee-the Commonwealth Textile, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee-which was in almost continuous operation assessing likely trends in the market, likely trends in imports, et cetera, and making recommendatons to the Government on at least an annual basis and sometimes more frequently about the appropriate size of quotas, market predictions and things of that kind. The industry has always had that sort of level of government intervention and, in some sense, some sort of guiding hand.

I share Senator Baume's view about the undesirability of what he described as interventionist authorities. However, I make the point that I think this is a particular case, particularly in light of the Government's proposal for the industries where there are a lot of things which require detailed coordination of administration-things such as skills training for the industry and market training for small firms in an effort to facilitate restructuring in a desirable way rather than an undesirable way and things which, in the circumstances we were faced with, justified an approach of this kind. I just make the point that the industry asked for such an authority. That does not mean that the Government should accede to that view. The industry asked for such an authority. That is important and has a lot to do with the history of developments in this industry.

My colleague Senator Lewis indicated that he opposed the Authority for a variety of reasons. I think that he saw it as not being necessary to implement the plan and said that there were too many bodies giving advice and that it might be costly and intrusive to the industry. The industry's answer to that is, `Thanks, we want to be intruded on. We would like the Authority'. Senator Lewis said that the Authority could be replaced by the Department. Of course it could. I think that there would be very little cost difference. If the Department is trying to manage an industry such as this it is arguably much more government interventionist, much more public sector interventionist, than an authority which is largely composed of people from the private sector with particular degrees of expertise. I have not yet announced the names of members of the Authority. Let me say that, apart from perhaps two people, if one analyses the composition of the Authority properly one will see that there is not a significant government presence on the Authority. It is very much a private sector presence with a knowledge of the industry and of the industry's needs-not, however, of the industry. I think there is a case for saying that it is more bureaucratic to have departments trying to manage these things rather than there being policy advisory bodies and so on. In those sorts of circumstances it is better to have an authority of this kind.

Senator Lewis was very flattering to the Department when he said that it could be faster and give more sensible and sensitive recommendations. Of course, as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, I share that view. Of course, public servants in my Department would give sensitive recommendations. Nonetheless, they would be recommendations that would have the characteristics of bureaucratic recommendations rather than the characteristic of recommendations of a group which is a little detached from the bureaucratic process.

I want to add some other reasons why I think it is desirable to have a monitoring advisory authority of the kind suggested in this legislation. Other alternatives were considered. The form proposed in the Bill was decided on because it had that complex range of functions, from monitoring the industries to advising on barrier protection issues-the function which used to be performed by the Elix Committee-and the development and administration of the industry's development strategy. That Authority will be independent of the Minister of the day, still responsible to him of course, and he responsible for it. I thought it was the unkindest cut of all for Senator Baume to say that in some ways the establishment of the Authority was an abdication of ministerial responsibility and that the device of appointing an authority was a way of getting me off the hook in here. Senator Baume has been unrelenting over the last 18 months or so in relation to the steel industry, where we have an authority. He ought to know better than anybody else that the mere existence of an authority does not get the Minister off the hook. I thought that was-how shall I put it?-uncharitable, coming from Senator Baume.

The Authority can be seen as more impartial and free from the day to day political pressures. It is accountable to Parliament. It will have a cross-section of capable people on the board. It will be assisted by a small secretariat expert in textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) matters and will have a finite life. I think that all those things are important. The form of authority proposed in the legislation is the form which the Government thought would be the most appropriate organisation to meet these needs.

I have not heard in detail all the speeches made in respect of this Bill. Senator Watson, if I might say so, with commendable consistency criticised me, as I understand it, for saying that the TCF plan is not immutable and that the industry should take into account other factors such as macro-economic circumstances. I can understand Senator Watson saying that, but this is a plan for a fairly long period into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated that it was merely an intermediate step.

—Senator Watson, if one learns by experience, which I certainly do, one will appreciate that in 1984, when we announced the motor vehicle plan, the pressures on the local industry at that time, which caused all sorts of falling about all over the place by the industry with company closures, large-scale sackings and all those sorts of things, were from Japan, the largest automotive manufacturing country in the world. There have been all sorts of changes since 1984, particularly the devaluation of the Australian dollar, which has changed those pressures significantly. The value of the yen as against the Australian dollar has perhaps removed most of those pressures. One has to have an opportunity of saying, `There have been enormously changed circumstances. We are entitled to look at that again'. For example, if things happen in the course of the multilateral trade negotiations which result in changes to the multi-fibre agreement, those changes will have an impact on the Australian industry because they will be significant factors in probably taking pressure off the Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: All these things are matters which possibly we will have to look at. That is why we have provided for mid-term review, and so on, which will also give the industry some assurance in the general context of the plan. That is what I mean by saying that the industry cannot be immutably protected, as it were, from the pressures that exist in the wider world. Certainly if there is a general change in tariff policy in Australia implemented by a government of any political persuasion, this industry would have to be considered in that context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some industry plans were after the realignment and some were before the realignment. This one, plus chemicals and plastics, are after the realignment of the currency. Therefore it would be unfair to group them with the other group whose plans were made prior to the realignment of the currency.

—I have not only permitted the honourable senator to interject; I have permitted him to make a speech. Indeed, if I may say so, it is a speech that I have heard before. Let us leave the currency argument aside. I think the honourable senator has made an important point; it is one which I essentially go along with. But supposing the average level of barrier assistance for all industries in Australia, including motor vehicles and TCF, is something of the order of 18 per cent tariff equivalent and the total environment changed. Would it not be appropriate to look at the question of TCF and the input costs and so on which it incurs? Supposing some levels of tariff protection for costs of inputs into TCF industries were removed completely. Would it not be appropriate in that circumstance to look at the TCF package? I think my answer to that question has to be yes. I think if, for a moment, Senator Watson ignores his past experience and his perceived constituency in Tasmania, and thinks about it in a rational way, he will agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I welcome the contribution which honourable senators have made to the second reading debate. Before I do anything else, I just want to indicate that in the course of the committee stage I will be introducing a number of amendments. Those amendments, which I will refer to in detail at the time of the committee stage debate, will be basically related to representations made by the industry to the Government. The industry made representations to the Government, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats. Those proposals of the industry have been accepted by the Government and the amendments which I will move during the committee stage will reflect that fact.

I want to conclude by making some general observations about the TCF industries. I am very optimistic and hopeful about the future of the TCF industries in Australia. But if any industries can be singled out, bar perhaps one which I have in mind and which I will not mention tonight--

TALK.START.PARA: —Steel yourself to do so.

—No, it is not steel. The industry I am thinking about is closer to the mouth. But if any industry can be singled out-and I am not seeking to make a political point about this-as having been allowed to develop in a bad policy environment by governments in the past, the TCF industries are examples of this. These industries perhaps did best in times of tailor-made protection on demand from governments. The solution to the problems was seen as not to push them into a greater level of international competitiveness, not for them to be seen in comparison with international industries, not for them to be aware of what was taking place in the international marketplace and in similar industries overseas, not to be conscious of all these things--
—Are you saying that output per employee is not comparable with the Europeans or even the Taiwanese?
—I did not say that at all. I am not talking about that.
—Competition really comes back to relative wage levels, does it not?

—If the honourable senator thinks that, we all have a long way to go. If he thinks it just comes back to relative wage levels, we all have real problems. To the extent that some of these industries are highly labour intensive, the answer to his question is yes. But not all of them are highly labour intensive.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that in terms of policy settings it was not good practice for governments of the past-and, again, I am not making a political comment-to encourage industries to go ahead in areas where they are highly labour intensive in competition with countries like Korea, Taiwan, Japan 15 or 20 years ago and so on. I do not think that was a good policy environment for industries to be encouraged to invest in and pretend that they could grow in in Australia. The fact of the matter is that these sorts of industries have got to move. That is what the structural adjustment process is about. To where do they move? In my view, they move into two areas. They move into areas where we have been particularly neglectful in the past-that is, into the areas of adding value to raw materials which we produce very successfully in this country.

The low level of wool fully processed in Australia is a disgrace. Again, it is something which developed here in the 1960s when this country just tried to do these things in a totally uncompetitive environment and so on. It is a disgrace in respect of wool, it is a disgrace in respect of cotton-and I heard Senator Coulter mention some of the figures and some of these things in his speech-and it is a disgrace in respect of hides.

We can make a significant contribution to national export income and import replacement by further processing these raw materials. It is now competitive for Australia to do that. We have to give a lot of encouragement for that to be done. The planning and strategic proposals for the development of the TCF industries gives a lot of emphasis to that. We can do those things now and we have to do them in terms of the economic problems which this country faces.

Secondly, like many other industries here, a considerable degree of talent is not being used by the TCF industries. This is particularly so in respect of clothing and textiles. There is a need to better use the talents of Australian people, whether they be designers, printers or even computer operators. The application of computers to textile design and so on is a development which has almost been ignored here by comparison with what happens in other countries. For example, Senator Watson could go into Marks and Spencers in London and say, `I want that shirt but I would like it purple instead of green'. His request would be punched into a computer in a store such as that and within two hours a shirt in his size and colour-exactly as he specified-would be ready for him. I have not seen that in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bigger market, though. It is all relevant to the size of the market.

—The honourable senator should stop making excuses for Australian industry. All the time the honourable senator wants to treat Australian industry like children and say, `You can never be in the real world, fellas, because you are babies'. That is what the honourable senator is saying to them all the time. That is not what it is about. I do not believe that. There is always some excuse. A couple of weeks ago Professor Wannecke from Stuttgart University and an industry economist gave a number of lectures to several Australian industries. He said to them, `You keep telling me that you cannot do these things because you might get a high valued dollar; you cannot do these things because you have high wages; and you cannot do these things because you have four weeks annual leave. I just remind you that Germany is the leading exporting country in the world. We have a highly valued currency. We have high wages-higher than in Australia. We have four weeks annual leave'. The simple point he was making to those audiences was: Do not all the time concentrate on the excuses; for a little while try and concentrate on the opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was trying to make is that the opportunities are now there. They have to be grasped by industries such as these. The Australian community cannot go on bailing them out. It cannot forever go on saying to them, `Put out your hand to the Government and we will look after you', because that is not an economic activity for this country to be involved in. I appeal to Senator Watson to lift his sights and not carry on in this mode of making excuses for people. One does not make excuses like that for the Australian cricket team when it loses; one says that it is no good.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you saying about the Labor Party last Saturday? Are you making excuses for it or are you saying that it is no good?

—I am not here to make a judgment on the Australian Labor Party tonight, but I have not made any excuses. I am not seeking to make any excuses now. Senator Lewis, as Opposition spokesman on industry, should not be lulled into the seductive, lazy, old-fashioned ways of his backbench colleague Senator Watson, who is sitting there giggling because he knows that what I am saying is correct. Senator Lewis knows as well as I do-he has on numerous occasions said it to me-that Australian companies are less imaginative than they ought to be.
—Be careful with what you are saying when you are quoting me.

—They certainly need a great deal of encouragement, which you are not giving them at the moment. All you are doing is kicking them.

—I am trying to encourage them at present. If Senator Lewis had been listening to me instead of dozing off, he would have appreciated what I was trying to say. One could go on with this discussion for a long time. The important point about this package of proposals is that we have to give these industries a bit of encouragement, a bit of initiative, a bit of a kick along to try to improve their performance in the direction I have indicated. I believe that honourable senators on both sides of the House can play a role in that. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

I move the amendments circulated in the Government's name.
The purpose of the amendments is to clarify the meaning of some clauses where there may be some confusion or concern and to reduce the formality for the conduct of inquiries by the authority.

In relation to inquiries, Part V of the Bill was based on similar legislation, for example the Steel Industry Authority Act, where that authority has the power to conduct inquiries. TALK.START.PARA: —In my response to the second reading debate I said, more bluntly than the tabling speech does, that the industry made representations to the Government, to the Liberals and to the Australian Democrats, and it is as a result of those representations that we made these changes. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the honourable senator that I believe the Authority and the Minister will be so locked in by conflicting interests in this industry that that will be the case.

Clause 10 (Report on TCF industries' matter etc.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 7, subclause 10(4), lines 29 to 36, leave out the subclause.

Let me explain to the Committee what clause 10, subclause (4) does. This is the dob-in clause. This clause provides that the Authority may prepare and give to the Minister a report on any instance that it considers is an instance of failure by a person involved in any of the TCF industries to act consistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government with respect to those industries. This Authority could report to the Minister that a company, for example, Bloggs Textiles Ltd, is not acting consistently with the Government's policies with respect to those industries.

I do not really know in what way the Minister had anticipated that this might be dealt with. The Government has all sorts of policies with respect to industries. The Government might have some policy whereby some industrial relations arrangements would be made or priority would be given to unionists on the question of employment. That might be this Labor Government's policy and this clause would require the Authority to report to the Minister that Bloggs Textiles Ltd, or whatever the name of the company is, is not acting consistently with the policies of the Commonwealth Government with respect to those industries in this matter. I say to the Committee that this is an extremely powerful clause. For some reason or other there is no requirement to publish the report. The Authority may recommend to the Minister that the whole or part of the report referred to in the subclause be published. I take it that the Minister may then accept or not accept that advice; in other words it will then be a matter for the Minister as to whether that part of the report is published.

Quite frankly, I am unable to see why we would want to have the power for the Authority, in effect, to dob in someone for not acting consistently with the Government's policies. That is different from someone not obeying the law or the Act in some way or other. I find this general reference to the Government's policies quite an extraordinarily wide power.

I might also mention that under subclause (3) the Authority may prepare and give to the Minister a report on any TCF industry matter anyway. So the Authority has an extraordinarily wide power there. I suppose that if the Authority wanted to report to the Minister that someone was not acting consistently with the Government's policies it could do so under subclause (3).

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a subterranean sort of dobbing in, isn't it? Without any legislative authority it is dobbing in in a way which I think you would find more reprehensible.

—I would certainly find it reprehensible; I agree with the Minister. But the point I am making is that if the Minister wants this Authority to have the power to dob in people, it already has this power under subclause (3). It is the Minister's Bill; it is not my Bill. So he wants the Authority to have this power and he cannot escape that by talking about subterranean dobbing in or anything else. It is his Bill. He brought the Bill into the Parliament and it has this power in it. I have pointed out that, under subclause (3), the Authority could report if it wanted to. But under subclause (4) of this Bill the Minister has directed the Authority specifically to go to this area. Subclause (4) opens up with the words:

SPEECH.PARA: Without limiting the generality of subsection (3) . . .

So the Bill, by its wording, acknowledges that under subclause (3) the Authority would have the power to do what the Minister wants it to do. The Minister specifically included this power in the Authority. The Minister has indicated in his amendments that he proposes that the Authority, before it dobs someone in or reports in this manner, would, firstly, give that person or that company notice that it intended to do so. How on earth would that help the company concerned? The explanatory memorandum says:

In clause 10 add: That the Authority shall, before recommending to the Minister that a report be published, notify any person to whom the report relates of the contents of the report and that it may be published.

In other words, if the Authority wants to report to the Minister that someone is not complying with the Commonwealth Government's policies and that that not be published, the person need not be notified. But if the Authority thinks the matter ought to be published, glory be, the Minister, very kindly, will notify that person that he will be reported to the Minister and that the Authority will recommend the report be published-in other words, be made public. I draw the Minister's attention to what the Law Council of Australia said in relation to its concerns:
It is not proper for Government to seek to impose obligations to comply with Government policy-it involves uncertainty and smacks of totalitarianism.

I thoroughly agree with the Law Council's report. I draw the Minister's attention to what Mr Garry Downes, QC, Chairman of the Administrative Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia, said in his memorandum which the Law Council sent to me and I am sure to the Minister and other honourable senators. Mr Downes says:
The most disturbing part of the Bill is cl.10, and, in particular, cl.10 (4).
He then explains what that clause does and he says:

Although there is at least one precedent for the granting of such a power to a Commonwealth Authority, that instance can be described as a special case. It seems to me that powers of this kind ought only very rarely to be granted, if at all.

Persons subject to Australian law have an obligation to abide by that law. That seems to me, however, generally, to be the proper limit of legislative interference. It does not seem to me that it is proper for Government to seek to impose obligations to comply with Government policy. Firstly, such an attempt smacks of totalitarianism. Why should a person acting within the law be under pressure to conduct himself in accordance with the wishes of the Government. Secondly, such a proposal suffers from great uncertainty: after all, what is Government policy; what is a failure to carry it out?
I think that it would be appropriate for the Parliament to at least pause before it enacts a provision such as cl.10.
My concerns prompted by the far reaching nature of this clause are only heightened by the provisions governing enquiries by the Authority which are contained in Part V of the Bill.

Just at the moment I am unable to put my hands on the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. But I would be very surprised if that Scrutiny of Bills Committee allowed this matter to pass without reference. Perhaps Senator Coulter will speak on this matter and refer to the Committee's report while I am looking for it. I say to the Minister quite frankly that the amendment proposed by the Government simply is not adequate. The best thing that could happen would be for the whole of clause 10 (4) to be deleted. In fact, the implication of Mr Downes is that the whole of clause 10 ought to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that. Come on!
—He says that clause 10 is his concern. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it would be appropriate for the Parliament to at least pause before it enacts a provision such as cl.10.
I thoroughly agree. I will look forward with interest to the Minister's explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not particularly excited by this provision in the legislation. I do not think that it is absolutely crucial. But it is not sufficient for Senator Lewis to describe it, as he says, as a dob in clause. That is a colloquialism which is understood outside the Senate, but perhaps not as well understood as it ought to be in the Senate. I quite understand Senator Lewis's view that the Parliament should pause before enacting provisions of this kind. TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to what the Minister has said in response to Senator Lewis. TALK.START.PARA: —Since 12 March this year Canberra has celebrated its seventy-fifth birthday and the birthday celebrations organised in this bicentennial year by the Canberra Festival Committee have been truly enjoyable. The great Australian balloon spectacular-a focus of this year's festivities-and the presence in Canberra of the wonderful contingent of veteran and vintage motor vehicles have contributed enormously to the atmosphere of the celebrations. There have been a host of other events and exhibitions which Canberrans have enjoyed during this time.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I particularly wish to speak about an event which, over three nights, had the people of Canberra enthralled-the son et lumiere production Versailles hails Canberra. Any honourable senators who were fortunate enough to be able to join the thousands of Canberrans who witnessed this event would agree that it was one of the most unique and impressive entertainments ever staged in Canberra, if not Australia. I take the opportunity to express my thanks and, I am sure, the thanks of the thousands who enjoyed the spectacular entertainment to the people responsible for the organisation and staging of the event.

The spectacle had its origin four years ago with the proposal that the cities of Canberra and Versailles be twinned. At that time, an approach was made to have the two cities twinned and this was pursued by the then leader of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) House of Assembly, Mr Jim Leedman. He visited Versailles in the Department of Yvelines and the proposition was put by the County Council of Yvelines that the two cities should twin. This in turn was put by Mr Leedman to the ACT House of Assembly and it was endorsed by that Assembly. It was about that time that the Federal Government abolished the House of Assembly. Recognising the importance of keeping the twinning plans in train, the House of Assembly decided to pass the matter over to a community committee which would continue the work which had been started. Mr John Kirby was appointed the chairman of that committee and the plans were modified slightly to twin not the cities, but the communities of Versailles-Yvelines and Canberra.

Mr Kirby visited Versailles in October 1986 to discuss the nature of the twinning arrangements and when reciprocal visits would be made by the representatives of the respective cities. It was agreed that a delegation from Canberra would visit Versailles in May 1987 for the first part of the twinning and that March 1988-our bicentennial year and on the occasion of Canberra's seventy-fifth birthday-would be an appropriate time for the reciprocal visit. In May 1987, 65 people from Canberra visited Versailles-Yvelines. An open invitation had been extended by the committee to anyone in Canberra wishing to be part of the delegation. A broad cross-section of people-all of whom paid their own fares-took the opportunity to be part of the visit. In Versailles a twinning ceremony took place and the delegation was entertained for four fabulous days-as I am told-by the County Council of Versailles-Yvelines and the people of that county.

In September 1987 Mr Kirby returned to Versailles to confirm the plans for March 1988. In response, Versailles-Yvelines sent six officials to Canberra in November of last year to finalise arrangements for the spectacular which was presented over the weekend. They discussed the logistics and indicated in detail the nature of the event they proposed to present. It became clear that it would be a major production-and it certainly was. The cost of staging the production was $1m. It involved 55 artists, dancers, actors and technicians. There were also 12 delegates from Versailles-Yvelines accompanying them and a number of Australian subcontractors involved in the staging. One may speak in superlatives to describe the lighting, the acting and costumes, the fountains, the music and the fireworks, but the total production left many absolutely speechless and feeling very emotional. It was a truly generous gift to Canberra on our birthday and to mark the twinning of our communities and the Australian Bicentennial. It was paid for largely by the Conseil General des Yvelines, but was also supported by a number of commercial sponsors including Grand Marnier, Le Notre Paris, Matra Espace, Technip, B.P. Rop, Cogema and Club Mediterranee and local sponsors included Canberra Building Society, Matrix and Price Waterhouse.

The benefits for Canberra from our twinned relationship with Versailles-Yvelines do not end with the enjoyment the production gave so many of us. The relationship is being developed to promote further exchanges between our communities because twinning of a community is a form of diplomacy. It is a means of people getting to know others. The Canberra Twinning Committee has been formed into an incorporated association-the Canberra-Versailles-Yvelines Twinning Committee Association-which is now raising funds to provide scholarships for Canberra students to study in Versailles-Yvelines. Student exchanges are already taking place. Cultural exchanges involving the Canberra City Band and the Canberra Symphony Orchestra are also distinct possibilities. While in some respects our cities are very different, they have a number of important similarities, such as their relationships to government. Canberra is a modern capital; Versailles was once the capital of France.

As a resident and representative of Canberra I look forward to seeing this relationship develop and our two cities prosper. I hope that Canberra may be able, in some measure, to return the generosity of the County Council of Versailles-Yvelines when the people of Versailles celebrate the 200th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille in 1989. The entertainment Versailles hails Canberra was said in the program to be proof of friendship. The event, the culmination of a splendid idea-the twinning of Canberra and Versailles-Yvelines-carried through by the communities of Canberra and Versailles-Yvelines and their citizens, is for the mutual benefit of the communities.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that January 1988 is the closing date for submissions to the independent Commission of Inquiry established by the Government of the Republic of Nauru.

(2) Does the Minister believe that the Australian Government has a responsibility to assist with the rehabilitation of areas of Nauru which were mined by the British Phosphate Commission while Nauru was under Australian administration.

(3) Is it true that, during the nearly fifty year period when Australia administered Nauru under the League of Nations Mandate and then under the United Nations Trust, Australia bought phosphate from Nauru for about one quarter of the world market price.
(4) Has the Australian Government made a submission to the Commission of Inquiry established by the Government of Nauru; if so, will the submission be made public; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (4) No. The Australian Government together with the other Partner Governments of the former British Phosphate Commissioners (New Zealand and British) regards the comprehensive phosphate agreement concluded in 1967 prior to Nauruan independence on 31 January 1968 as a just settlement that cleared the Partner Governments of any responsibility for the rehabilitation of Nauru. The Australian Government has therefore not made a submission to the Nauru Commission of Inquiry, which has no legal standing in Australia. Further to Senator Macklin's question of 24 November in the Senate, the Government has under consideration what access to information can be granted to the Government of Nauru.
(3) No. The cost of phosphate varied over the period. It was generally lower than market prices because the British Phosphate Commissioners operated on a cost recovery rather than profit basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 3 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian International Development Aid Bureau completed its review of Australia's international aid programmes; if so, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade be making the findings of this review public; if not, why not.

(2) Is the Minister aware that Australia is the only Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member country of the agricultural fund which has not yet honoured its pledge to make a grant to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD-2), the second stage of the fund.

(3) Will the Australian Government fulfil its pledged second replenishment to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD-2) amounting to $8.48 million; if so, when will this replenishment be made; if not, why not.

(4) Does the Minister agree that through the International Fund for Agricultural Development there is an important contribution made to assisting the rural landless and low income small farmers in developing countries; if so, will he give an assurance that Government funding for the International Fund for Agricultural Development will continue after IFAD-2; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I assume that the honourable Senator is referring to the in house review by AIDAB of Australia's membership of International Financial Institutions (the IFI Review) carried out by Cabinet direction. This review focused on Australia's participation in the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. As the IFI Review was prepared for and considered by Cabinet it is classified Cabinet-in-Confidence. In keeping with the conventions and principles of Cabinet confidentiality, the IFI Review will not be released publicly.

(2) As the honourable Senator will be aware from my press release of 8 November 1987 and from my answer to his questions of 20 October 1987, Australia will be honouring its pledge of $A8.48 million to the second replenishment of IFAD. An instrument of contribution will be lodged with IFAD once the enabling legislation has received Royal Assent.
(3) Yes. See answer to question 2 above.

(4) No. The second reading speech which accompanied the International Financial Institutions appropriation bills, provided details on this decision (see House of Representatives Daily Hansard, Thursday 19 November 1987, pp 2361-2364). In particular, I draw the Honourable Senator's attention to an article in the Canberra Times of 24 August 1987 ``Shortage of aid funds points up IFAD inefficiencies'' by Professor Helen Hughes of the Development Studies Centre at the Australian National University.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 17 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the advertisement in the Public Notices column on page 25 of The Age on 17 September 1987 headed ``Notice of Cancellation of Passport'' and signed by S. C. Moon, Secretary, Telecom Australia.
(2) Why did the Consul of the People's Republic of China request that the advertisement be published, and why did Telecom need to comply with the request.
(3) Who is Ma Yin Ping and what is the connection between that person, the passport and its cancellation, and Telecom.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) Mr Ma Yin Ping is the Deputy Director, Design Division, Fourth Engineering Corporation in Zheng Zhou's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China. Under the terms of Memorandum of Understanding between Telecom Australia and the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China, Mr Ma Yin Ping was in Australia from 13 September 1987 to 24 October 1987, on a work experience tour visiting Telecom Australia establishments to study optical fibre systems. Mr Ma Yin Ping's passport and personal effects were stolen from his hotel room on 15 September 1987.

The Consul General of the People's Republic of China informed Telecom that their policy required that a notice be placed in daily papers at least one week before a passport could be issued to replace one which had been lost or stolen. As Telecom was responsible for the visitor under the Memorandum of Understanding and naturally wished to assist in the replacement of his passport, it complied with the Consul General's request.
